Then they attempt to sell me another printer over the phone!!! What a JOKE!This was a printer that I rarely used and it died only after 13 months after I forked out $100 bucks for ink.

Title: Printhead failure 3 months after warranty
Review: I was very happy with this printer, scanner (did not use the fax) until I replaced the last setup ink cartridge (Magenta) a few weeks ago with a new 951XL.  All the setup cartridges (ones installed at time of purchase) have been replaced in the last month with authentic HP cartridges.  The printer/scanner is dead and all I get is printhead failure, reinstall or replace.  I just spend $100 on authentic HP ink cartridges (which is way too much) and now cant even use them.  I cant even use the scanner because I cant clear the error from the panel.  How can this expensive inkjet copier/scanner printhead fail with about 1 year of light use.  HP you disappoint me.  Their support forum recommends to others that have had the same issue to buy a new printer.  Another USA company that is creating crap product and dont care about long term relationship with customers.  I need this machine to work.  If anyone has found a way to resolve this issue please reply (I'm sure to get an answer here faster than on HP forum).  If I had not thrown away the empty Magenta setup cartridge I would have put it back in just to see if the printhead would work again.  Something hinkey about all these printhead failures.  I guess the CEOs at HP have enough money to buy a new 8600 every year.

Title: Perfect All-in-One solution for small businesses
Review: After years of using my HP-1150 All-in-One printer, the time came to upgrade and I definitely made the right choice.  I stuck with HP because I had been happy with my previous printer the five plus years I was using it.Out of the box the 8600 was very simple to install.  Wireless options, color touch screen display, scan from feeder, wireless printing – look through the feature list yourself but I cannot say a single bad thing about this printer.  It has improved my office functionality by leaps and bounds!

Title: Performed As Advertised.
Review: This is my 5th generation of HP printers...I expect and receive reliable performance. I recommend this great product.Dallas

Title: Dead on arrival
Review: Such a shame; capable of many potentially useful functions, but constantly reads "paper jam" regardless of the issue that needs to be addressed. I normally don't pay attention to reviews online, but 90 1 stars on Amazon should mean something. Also, this complaint appears on other online sites.I don't think it has worked successfully for more than 10% of the time I've owned it.A frustrating experience.

Title: Like the product but having trouble finding answers to operating questions using online tools.
Review: When try to make copy from computer, unit comes up in fax mode so have to use dropdown menu to change to printer mode.  Inputing this information into online site gets list of genaric instructions which are useless for the problem.  Need to improve process or provide a good old fashioned operators manual.

Title: Very happy with this printer.
Review: Very happy with this printer.  I don't use it heavily...maybe three to five times per week but have been happy with its performance.

Title: piece of junk
Review: Do not  buy this printer unless you want all kinds of error messages, paper jams, and poor quality printing of colored documents.  Very slow as well.Bought one in June and immediately had problems mentioned above...was told probably just a dud machine.  Replaced with same printer, SAME problems.  Got in contact with HP and they said it was because it was plugged into a surge protector(apparently one in machine per woman on phone), so connected to power without surge protector.  That was not the problem! I believe it is the poor quality of the machine, worse and worse as the years go on.This is the first review I've ever posted.  Just had to vent and let others know about this printer.S Ward

Title: Unfixable just shortly after a year
Review: We purchased this printer in July of last year and have been happy with it until now.  Yesterday I noticed that the display was blank--all white. I can still print, but am now unable to fax, copy, or scan since I cannot select anything from the display. I called HP Tech Support today and after troubleshooting, found out that it is a hardware issue.  HP can do nothing.  The tech support said that our warranty was 100 days out of date, which means that HP only warrants their product for 6 months.  It's basically junk after a year.  Boo.I don't recommend buying this product, unless you purchase a majorly extended warranty.

Title: Fast with great interface
Review: I have had several printers over the years, and I absolutely love this printer.  The only downside based on my needs is that it is quite large.  What I particularly like compared with previously owned printers:  - goes into sleep mode when not in use, but comes out of sleep mode quickly when job received  - very fast print start time.  The per page print time advertised by printers is meaningless if it takes a full minute or more before the printing starts.  This printer starts printing within a few seconds, even when in sleep mode.  - very fast print including full color, high resolution pictures.  When I printed a page of pictures and it was completed in a few seconds, including time to come out of sleep mode, I thought something had happened to interrupt the printout.  But, when I went to retrieve the page to see what happened, there it was, the full picture.  - printout quality is excellent  - 2-sided copy/scanning easy to use, feeder works well  - initial setup was quick and painless, had no issues using the first time  - tray holds 250 sheets of paper, not constantly running out mid-print  - ink usage is minimal, after printing quite a few pages including pictures, the ink still shows as nearly full, easy to check ink status from printer or computer  - touch screen to control the printer is well laid out, easy to read and responsive to the touch  - useful to print from iphone or email, can send a printout from work and it is waiting for me when I arrive homeBasically the printer is easy to use, fast and has the functionality I most need.  I have not had any performance issues and highly recommend it.

Title: Not for graphics or heavy paper- text only...
Review: I was excited to get this printer but have been deeply disappointed at what it turned out to be.  I purchased it directly from HP.I print a lot of cardstock and graphics as well as text.  I also occasionally print photos.  This printer bungles everything but plain text on plain paper.Pros:this unit is huge and it prints black text okay.Cons:* The print quality for graphic is quite poor compared to anything I've used in the last several years.  Even at the highest quality settings, every graphic has streaks through it and the speckles throughout - something I'm not used to seeing in a printer that claims to be able to print photos.* This does not deal nicely with heavy papers (HP premium photo paper, cardstock or otherwise) - it puts a nice wrinkle at the top/center of every sheet.* Configuration is awkward - want to scan a document to your computer? you need to download and install another HP program/client on your computer and try to get it configured. Funny, but with my previous printers, I easily selected the desired destination folder for scans upon initial setup and then was off and running.  Want to use the e-print feature?  Have fun setting it up.* The USB and memory card slots are of limited functionality.  They can only read jpg files for direct printing (you can't transfer anything to your computer from them).I wish I could get my money back from HP for this.

Title: It works as expected
Review: What I would expect....sort of noisy when operating....will expect to run out of ink soon and be charged and outlandish price for replacement......

Title: What HP doesn't want you to know about this printer
Review: I have to admit, the cartridges that come with the printer last for a long time, and at first I was very happy with this purchase. But then I learned the hard way that this printer steals your ink in 2 REALLY sneaky ways:1) This printer will not let you print if ANY ONE of the cartridges is empty. Yes, you read that correctly. Despite having 4 independent ink cartridges that you can replace... you cannot actually run out of any ink if you want to keep printing. For example, you have a term paper due and this printer runs out of Magenta. You think, WHEW! No problem, I'm just printing Black and White text... NOT WITH THIS PRINTER! DON'T PLAN ON JUST PRINTING IN BLACK INK!! (SEE 2).2) Even if you select the option to 'Only Print in Black Ink' THIS PRINTER WILL STILL USE YOUR COLOR INK. Just search for 'hp officejet pro 8600 won't print black only' to see what you're in for. (I wish I had searched that... before I had several cartridges of color ink stolen by HP engineers).These 2 points combine to form a nightmarish cycle of needless cartridge purchases and printing 'lockdowns', i.e. times where the printer won't work ... even though it could work.If you run into #1) you can (in a REAL pinch) put tape over the oblong hole of the empty cartridge to trick the printer into thinking it's full. This will void your warranty and could ruin your printer (ink could dry in the printhead). There is no fix for #2.[Updated 11/13/2013 to reflect that unlike previous versions of the HP 8000 series printer, this version does not actively block users from printing after print cartridges digitally 'expire'.)

Title: HP 8600 Plus combo printer
Review: I really love this printer! I've had a whole series of HP's over the years. The last one was the 7900, which was beginning to chew up print cartridges so I decided it needed to be replaced. Given how inexpensive the 8600 plus was, I wasn't expecting how much I'd like it. For example, the new method of quoting print speeds had me thinking it was slower than the 7900; instead it was blazing fast in comparison. I had no idea how addictive the automatic double-sided printing (and scanning) would be, especially when coupled with a utility program I've had for years called Clickbook. In a flash, 50 or 60 page manuals are printed as 12-15 page booklets. In the past, I had to go through a user-intensive stage of printing one side, waiting for it to complete, then putting the paper back into the paper tray, and printing the other side. I also frequently use Hallmark's Card Studio greeting card program and again I just send the card to print and it comes out with both sides printed perfectly with no extra effort on my part.The wireless is also a good addition. I could have set up my 7900 that way, but I never did, probably because I'd had problems with other supposedly wireless printers. This one though was easily set-up and works like a charm.

Title: Really like it
Review: When I first got this it didn't print. Turns out it was a dirty inkjet dispenser. I cleaned it with a clean cotton cloth & rubbing alcohol and it works great. It was brand new so I don't know why the cartridge dispenser was covered with black ink. But since I cleaned it no problems. Easy to set up. Wireless works great. I installed the printer software on both an XP machine and a Win7 machine even though the two machines are networked (that's a whole other story). I've only had it a month but so far I am extremely pleased. One thing I would say is that the OCR software is not as good as my previous printer, a Lexmark. The Lexmark would render any complex scanned doc in Word w. near 100% perfection. Considerable less so with this OCR software. But that aside the printer is top notch. The touch screen is cool. I don't think you'll be disappointed with this printer. At least I'm not.BTW; that Lexmark was a piece of junk.

Title: Indispensable for home office
Review: What I like about tis all in one is its ability to duplex scan and print, high capacity paper tray, and the ability to print to it while out of the office with ePrint. Ink cartridges last longer than many I have used and HP is bringing a cloud based feature onlinf that will monitor your ink usage and automatically send you new cartridges as needed for a fee.

Title: Does What It Says
Review: It does everything it says it can. Wireless printing, scanning to dropbox, scanning to email. Scanning and printing from the printer, iPhone, and computer all works flawlessly.You will need to be moderately tech savvy to set up all the different scanning options.

Title: Everything I Could Want In An AIO Printer!
Review: Time In Use:  5 MonthsThis was purchased for use in my office at work.  This AIO really does it all and does it very well.  I love the convenience and ease-of-use of the large color LCD touch screen.  Making copies and scans could not be any easier.  I've found that the print quality is excellent for text and presentation graphics.  Photo quality is also quite good.  Very fast printing.Cons:  Occasionally connection to the printer is lost when transferring photos from an inserted SD card to PC connected via USB.  I have to pull out the card, reinsert it, and reselect the photos to be transferred.  I wish there was a manual feed slot for printing on envelopes, card stock, etc.  Occasionally, scans of documents using the ADF are a little crooked.All in all, I am very impressed and pleased with this printer.  I bought a second 8600 to replace an aging monochrome laser at home.

Title: A good and faithful printer.
Review: Does about everything well except envelopes.It seems to sip on the ink. I get lots of copies off of one black cartridge.

Title: Great Product!
Review: The product exceeded my expectations!  It has made a big difference in the ease of printing, etc for my small business.

Title: Excellent for Home Office
Review: The HP Pro 8600 is fast and quiet. It prints sharp black and white and excellent color. The front panel walks you through any setup with pictures and clear instructions. The color cartridges are each separate so you don't have to buy 3 colors if all you need is red. The feeder is reliable and it handles legal-sized documents. At the price it is a great printer for a home office.

Title: Replaced an 8600 Pro
Review: In late 2011 I purchased an HP 8600 Pro. BIG MISTAKE. I had nothing but trouble with it. HP sent me a replacement because it was still under warranty.  The replacement was just as bad. So, HP replaced with my current 8600 Plus.  I've had it working since February 2012 and until recently it worked great. Setup out of the box was easy, including setting up the network.  Scanning is a breeze, but wish it were faster.  I love the 2 sided printing and the auto feed top feeder plus the large paper tray.Recently, I began having trouble with color printing.  I have had to repeatedly remove and replace the cartridges, run cartridge alignments and clean printheads.  Today, I think it reached it's limit.  I ran every self test and correction method I could find.  The last instructions I received was that I needed to replace my print heads. OUCH! This is expensive.  When calling HP I learned that the printhead will cost me $120.  For $70 more I can buy an all new 8600 Plus.I have to admit that I am a power user printer.  I run a small insurance business from my home and I go through paper like nobody's business.  So, I'm not surprised that the printheads are shot.I also love that I can order the XL cartridges which are more cost effective AND they last longer.  I have never been able to figure out how to E-Print though.  And I don't have time to mess with trying to set it up so I just let that feature go.  I also love the faxing capability because I can store frequently used fax numbers and just pull them up and hit send.  GREAT feature!  It's also nice to just touch the display to see where ink levels are sitting.  I have printed a few photos on this printer and it does an acceptable job.  But then, I didn't buy it to print photos.Now I'm shopping for another printer and it looks like it's going to be the 8600 Plus AGAIN.  I have no major complaints about this machine, I'm used to the way it works, it's quirks, the print quality and the setup.  So, here I go, biting the bullet again.  I have past computer sales experience and HP has always been the top choice for me in printers.

Title: Best Printer and Great Price
Review: This printer for the value is excellent. The ink cartridges are lasting much longer than my last HP printer. The wireless is seamless, easy to set up. Print back to back, fantastic. Scan/fax all great. The service of the shipper was great. Arrived much faster than I expected.

Title: HP Officejet Pro 8600 Plus
Review: Great printer.  I have two in my office.  I replaced a HP laser printer.  The Ink jet cartridges lasted longer and cost less than the laser toner cartridges under the same conditions. The 8600 print quality was as good and sometimes better than the laser printer.

Title: Works fine.
Review: There were a few times things did not print but we think it was probably a computer problem rather than the printer. The copies are fine and it seems easy to use.

Title: This is my second 8600
Review: I had already purchased this model with the extra paper drawer.  It is upstairs in my office.  This one is downstairs in the corner of the family room.  I als bought this model as a gift for a very close friend she loves it.  I like the tray that allows you to copy a stack of items, fax a stack of items, scan a stack of items.  I also like that you can email something you want printed from anywhere to the printer.  I print directly from my iPad and iPhone.  I have recommended this printer to other people and to my knowledge 3 other people have bought it and love it as much as I do.  It also has applications.  Every night about 2, a crossword puzzle is printed, one of many apps available.  I love crosswords.

Title: Won't print with Costco 8 1/2 x 11 photo paper
Review: I rely on the printer to also have the capacity to print on photo paper as much as regular paper.And while I'm happy with both the quality of the printer on regular paper, as well as HP customer support, there is a flaw in this printer that won't allow Costco photo paper to be used.  The printer just doesn't recognize it.Alas, the printer has to be returned to Costco.

Title: HP Officejet Pro 8600 Plus - Fair Deal
Review: Set-up....as expected.Operation - as expected.Ink usage rate....too early to tell, haven't owned it long enough yet.Only negative is the "Caller ID" feature....How the heck to you enable it? I've searched and searched and apparently so have many other HP Officejet Pro 8600 Plus owners. HP, as far as I can tell, hasn't answered in a positive/effective message, just how to do that...Other than that, it works fine, so far.

Title: Great printer.
Review: Bought one month ago. Prints very nicely. No problems setting up with wifi. Have tried printing remotely and that worked perfectly. Have not tried printing pictures yet will let you know.

Title: Great Printer
Review: Excellent printer. Functions work as advertised. Very satisfied with this purchase. I recommend this printer to anyone that required the features this machine offers.

Title: Exactly what I needed
Review: Great printer/scanner.  Very easy to set-up and use.  Just what I needed, but it is a big sucker, so if you're cramped for space, you may not want something this big.  If you've got the room, go for it.

Title: Down to 2 from 5 Stars
Review: I have had this about 9 months now. LOVED it when I first got it. Set it up myself (I usually have to have my son help with computer stuff.)It prints, it scans, it is awesome! And then...had to reinstall the drivers at least 5 times now. It won't print with Internet Explorer, have to switch to a different browser. OK. Love it so much putting up with all that stuff. But today... Printer notifies me my Yellow ink cartridge is low, but says 'don't worry about it' just get one to have on hand. Two seconds later will not print (even black and white) because Yellow cartridge is TOTALLY GONE apparently. Go buy $60 worth of the 3 color cartridges (replaced the black a couple weeks ago with no problem at all.) Replace the Yellow. It tells me a cartridge is defective and needs to be replaced-go get a new cartridge. Umm. I just did. Take it in and out about 3 times. Turn the printer off and on about 3 times. OK. Now it tells me the Cyan cartridge is low. OK, got that with the Yellow. Same thing--the cartridge is defective and turn off and on and put in and out and finally OK. Then it still won't won't print...so I think What the Heck? and go ahead and replace the new Blue Cartridge. Prints and everything is fine.I loved this at first, but I so definately would not buy it again. It is the most annoying printer I have ever had. I traded in a 17 year old printer (black and white only) that still worked perfectly to get this. Had a separate scanner and separate fax machine and wanted the All In One. Well, right now, I want all my old stuff back and this to go away.

Title: Shop this printer price carefully
Review: This printer can currently be purchased on the HP site new for $150 with free shipping, a lower price than any option on this page and its links for new, used, refurbished.  Unfortunately I paid $175 for a refurbished one. My refurb came without a manual, so I will have to find it on the internet - no big deal since I can rarely find a manual when I need it.As best I can tell, none of the units include printer cartridges which will set you back another $100 or so.I have a similar older model with which I have been extremely satisfied.One reviewer said this printer will not accommodate 14 inch paper. Mine has a blue release inside the paper holder that releases it to accommodate 14 inch paper.Printer warns to leave printer on so as to prevent printer damage if print cartridges are absent.  If comes without cartridges, then what?  Damage?

Title: False claims about media types and media sizes
Review: This printer was great for printing documents and was extremely easy to set up. However, it would not accept any type of paper other than regular 8.5x11 document paper. I tried various HP photo papers of all different sizes and every time I received an error message stating that "paper tray is empty, please load paper." After reading through a lot of the negative reviews, I came to realize that this is a common problem with this printer. To make matters worse, the Amazon vendor (PCRUSH) did not provide return shipping labels. I had to pay $30 to ship the return.In short, this is probably a great printer for someone who does not care about printing photos or graphics and is strictly looking for a document printer with scanning and faxing capabilities. Otherwise don't waste your time.

Title: What a great printer!
Review: The HP Officejet Pro 8600 Plus is a great printer! It does everything I want it to do. Two-Side to One-Side and vice versa as well as scanning  the same way. Setting up the network was easy and now we can print wirelessly from anywhere in the house from all our moble devices. I can't say enough on how well it works! It's a great buy and free shipping really tops off a great deal.

Title: Not a good experience!
Review: The printer started malfunctioning the first day and continued to get worse.  Contacted the seller and was told that he could not replace the unit because he did not have anymore of them.  Had to call HP and go through tech support 3 times and was finally told that the printer was defective.  Finally got a replacement after 2 weeks of dealing with a defective printer (Was a headache, but, eventually got a new printer).  Not a good experience.

Title: Great
Review: This is one of the easiest printer combos we have ever owned and set up. It works all the time and is great quality

Title: Nice
Review: I would buy this again. Once you find a happy wireless spot you will have no connection troubles. very modern options

Title: Sleek design
Review: I had a Officejet 7700p all in one, which was a little more professional.  It had the 2 drawers for paper, which was nice, because every time I want to print an envelope now I have to take all the paper out of this new 8600 and put one or two envelopes in.  Also the paper tray is low to the ground or surface of where the printer sits, so you have to keep the area clear of things cause the drawer has to be completely pulled all the way out.Other than that, it scans (So far..I only scanned two items so far) and prints from my iphone, which is an improvement and one of the reasons for the new printer.  I have the old one upstairs with my tenant.  So I'll see how it goes.  I actually bought two of these, so we'll see.Consumer reports gives this printer an exceptional rating, EXCEPT a BLACK CIRCLE for wasting print cartridge ink during maintenance.  Something to think about..

Title: Great printer & not too expensive
Review: Great printer & not too expensive.  It's been used in a small office and it's great.  Setup is a little tedious, but you're good to go once it's done.

Title: I Still Like It
Review: Printer is as advertised, big but I have the space for it. Set up for me with I print was very easy and I usually have problems setting up anything. I did have to call help line to determine why the unit would not print photos on photo paper other than HP. Got right thru to service and they were extremely nice and perhaps helpful. They said HP paper had bar code that computer read although I didn't see any when purchased. I think it has to do with the weight of the photo paper but haven't experimented yet. Both print and photos very very good. Double sided works great. Have not used fax, or scan but did not buy it for that. Last HP printer I bought lasted @ 13 years. Check with me in ten years and I'll give you an update.

Title: Excellent quality and a bargain wjem considering life cycle cost
Review: I would recommend this for both individuals and small offices.Everything works remarkably well--whether it be the user interface, duplexing, and the like. The printer display leads you easily through the initial setup and provides quick and easy access to all the printer functions.  It is fast, efficient, and both the B&W and color print quality are quite good.  (I don't use this for photo printing I should note, but I am a photographer that makes demands beyond what might reasonably expect from what is essentially an office printer. I have a larger format printer with better user control for color management for that work.)Even for individuals, if one uses the extra large ink cartridges, the savings in ink will quickly pay for any difference in purchase price between this and a  less expensive and less capable printer. The duplexing offers opportunity for further savings in paper costs.

Title: HP Printers are junk
Review: I have an HP Officejet Pro 8500 series. This thing takes forever to go through its 'warm up cycle', and during this cycle wastes all off the damned ink. I seldom print anything and therefore do not turn my printer on that often. When I do print something it is in grayscale i.e.; I never print in color, I have no need, however my color ink has to be replaced constantly. It is not cheap! It must be HP's way of screwing the un-knowing consumers who buy their lousy product. Stay away from HP printers. Buying an HP printer leads to aggravation and loss of money from buying their super expensive ink cartidges. RIP-OFF City!!!!!!!

Title: NOT what it claims to be
Review: Let me start off that this is a very good printer IF you are willing to jump through many, many hoops to get it to print wirelessly.  I have a brand new Mac and the printer WILL NOT PRINT wirelessly.  The problem is widely known online, and there are many suggestions for a fix, if you are willing to wade through that minefield. I only assume HP knows about the issue but were entirely unhelpful with tech support.  It seems the printer must be assigned a static IP address in order for it to wake up from sleep, otherwise it just hangs.I would have purchased a different printer entirely if I had know I'd need an IT guy to set it up. Again, great printer but zero stars for set up and wireless use.

Title: Everything it claims to be
Review: Got it super fast.  It was very easy to set up.  Prints very fast and does very good photo printing.  It's photo quality Isn't quite as good as my wife's printer that is for that purpose.  I really like the printing from my kindle.  Very satisfied.

Title: Super All in One
Review: I love this copier!!! Very easy to link to my home network and its super fast!!! Wow, wow, wow wow.

Title: Does everything I expected.
Review: Had a little problem install software on xp. Tech support excellent. Printer does exactly what it is suppose to do.

Title: Have a Mac?  Don't buy this printer.
Review: This is my second weekend in a row I have spent 8 or more hours trying to configure the eprint features to enable scanning and printing to a network folder from a Mac. This is also the second printer since after spending hours on the phone with HP support I was instructed to return it to my place of purchase. The second one is no better interns of configuring these features for a Mac. Instructions for configuration refer to menus and settings that don't even appear in the software and the HP customer support was terrible. They were unresponsive to email requests for support and phone support was very frustrating and lengthy. It it weren't so big and heavy I would be back in the store with this product. How disappointing...

Title: Do not buy HP8600
Review: I'm on my second unit and it does not work.  I have spent countless hours trying to upload new software, etc.  The printer goes to sleep and will not print once it comes out of it.  I have printing issues as well.  I'm about to get my money back for this printer and buy a different brand.  Do not buy this printer.

Title: Great Home Office Printer with Smartphone/Tablet/Cloud Printing!
Review: This is a great printer.After setting up the printer by using the on-screen display and adding the printer to your wireless network, simply print out the details of the wireless settings.Now go into the printer's website by entering the IP address into your computer's web browser which is also on the same network usually 192.168.0.x.Then just assign a static IP address for the printer, so that it won't change randomly, mine was 192.168.0.250.Now turn off your router, and your printer.  Then boot your router and wait for the lights to stop flashing and the connection lights to be stable, and then boot your printer.Now simply print out the details of the wireless settings and confirm your new IP is 192.168.0.250.That's it.  Everything else should work now.-You can download HP ePrint - which allows you to print from the web, email, the cloud, and your photos too.-You can download HP Printer Control - which allows you to control scanning, faxing, and all the features within network.-You can send emails directly to your printer's email address, and it will print all attachments within the email, 'from the cloud.'-Plus you can download apps onto the printer from the HPconnected website and the ePrintercenter website, which is neat.-Basically this printer does way more than I will ever need it to do.Con:  You will need to be somewhat computer literate to assign your static IP address, and understand the basics of turning off your router and printer in the correct order.  I'm an IT professional, so this is a non-issue for me, and took me less than 3 minutes, but you will notice the vast majority of negative reviews are people that can't tie their technical shoes.

Title: Fast speed
Review: Love my new printer it prints fast and is super easy to install and to connect to the network. comes with full amount of ink too

Title: Quality Printer
Review: This is my second 8600 printer. I was so impressed with the first that I purchased this upgrade printer. HP always has a good product full of features and this one does not disappoint.

Title: How did this get over 2 star ratings?????
Review: I can't think of anything I like about this printer. It is loud and takes a full minute of clicking, clanging, and other gyrations when you make your first copy and its not much better for following prints. Photo quality is TERRIBLE!!! I 'm already looking for a different new printer. I just wish I had returned it when I could. I haven't used the feeder much, but it seems everytime I have something really important to print or fax, the paper feeds unevenly and so the copy is lop sided or your 'master' copy is jammed and wrinkled or torn IF and when you get it removed. What else can I say?? I believe that sometimes a product works great and gets great reviews, the manufacter then starts 'cutting corners' trying to save money and ends up with a piece of junk like this. The best printer I EVER had was an HP and I could kick myself for getting rid of it. Now I'm kinda of leary of the ratings on a product. I'd advise passing on this one.

Title: DO NOT WASTE YOUR MONEY
Review: This is by far the worst printer I have ever owned. It is a waste of money, many times over. And what I mean by  many times over, is that you will be buying a ton of paper and ink, and wasting a HUGE amount of time, printing and REPRINTING and REPRINTING, because the paper feeder starts to feed in more than one sheet at a time, and jacks up your print job.So, you end up printing your jobs ONE SHEET AT A TIME to make sure it prints correctly. Or, if you take a (stupid) leap of faith and think it will print correctly, you have to sift thru and find out which pages mis-printed, re-print those, sort thru THOSE to find the misprints, re-print those, and then throw away a couple trees' worth of paper and expensive ink.Piece of CRAP.

Title: Officejet Pro 8600 plus - Love it
Review: Great all out printer. A few things I could not get HP support to help with but worth noting for anyone considering this printer. After you get it setup and the IP address is assigned.To get it to Scan to E-Mail it must be configured with an Ethernet connection to your router. (USB or Wireless will not allow Scan to Email).Open your internet explorer and type in the address of your printer. Go to the networking tab at top. On the left panel you will see,Wired (802.3)StatusIPv4IPv6AdvancedGo to the IPv4 and under the DNS change it  to the following. Manual DNS Server and DO NOT USE your primary router as IP as a DNS. Use any other like Primary 8.8.8.8  Secondary 8.8.4.4 which happen to be Google DNS.Also if you want to print to a Network folder you will have to add a Username and password for your windows on the computers you wish to save to through the network.

Title: Great Printer
Review: Easy to set upPrints great, Copy and fax work great as well.Recommend it to anyone who wants a versatile printer.

Title: Fantastic Printer - But Beware of High Tech Big Brother
Review: To me, there are no 'cons' with this fantastic printer combination. However, at the time of purchase, I did not realize that, on this particular model (as well as other models), HP has inserted a micro chip in each of the printer ink cartridges. What that means is that whenever any cartridge is depleted (color or black ink) the owner of the machine cannot print anything until each of the depleted cartridges is replaced by, of course, an authentic HP printer cartridge. I feel as though I'm being held hostage in my own home/office by HP. Normally, when color cartridges are depleted, I continue to print black and white; just to save a little money. If a good class action attorney reads this review, it might be a good case to consider.

Title: No more HP
Review: I've only had this printer for a few months and have printed less than 1200 sheets. Now I'm running into issues with splotchy and incomplete character or image printing. It won't print the color red, and sometimes I'm seeing green when printing black. I've cleaned the print head - twice, through all 3 levels of cleaning and just pouring ink down the drain with the test pages. The next menu solution is to replace the print head. I've got a better idea, I'm going to replace the printer! No more HP anything - and this comes from someone who has used HP everything over many years (15+) and now - nothing but disappointment. Don't waste your money on this unit.

Title: Worked until the original ink ran out...
Review: I bought this printer less than a year ago in October of '12. Initially I was happy with it. It did a good job printing, it was fast, it was wireless, and the ink lasted a long time.  However, when the yellow and black ink ran out I bought a new set of genuine HP ink cartridges. When I installed the two new cartridges, the printer verified that they were genuine HP cartridges (which I bought from Amazon), and proceeded to go through the "preparing" process that the printer goes through when a new cartridge is installed. Immediately at this point the printer froze up with a "Printer Failure" error on the screen. The printer screen had a message stating that "There is a problem with the printer or ink system. Turn printer off, then on. If problem persists, contact HP." Of course after several attempts of turning the printer off and back on, as directed, as well as taking the cartridges back out and putting them in again, the error message still showed up. I then tried putting the original two cartridges back in, but the error stayed the same. There was no way to reset it. There was not even a message stating that the old cartridges were empty or anything to that effect; just the same "printer failure" message.At this point I was very frustrated. I spent $200 dollars on this printer (plus $112 worth of ink) and got less than a year of use out of it.  Once the original cartridges were used up, the printer is now junk.I Googled the problem and found an HP site to check to see if the printer was still under warranty.  HP indicated on the site that the warranty had expired back in April of this year (just six months after purchase). I filled out a petition form to challenge that expiration date, so we'll see how that goes. If HP will ends up honoring the warranty I'll revise my review to reflect that goodwill gesture. However, even at that point I'm afraid that HP will likely charge me for the shipping, and I'll still be out of a printer for a few weeks. Either way, this has been a very disappointing purchase.As I mentioned before, I was initially happy with this printer, but the final outcome has turned into a disaster. If HP doesn't honor the warranty (for at least a year) I think I'll be done with HP for good.For now I'll have to wait...without a printer................................................Wish me luck.

Title: BUYER BEWARE!!! DO NOT BUY HP OFFICEJET 8600!!!
Review: So let me first start off with the only good note on this printer, like the other reviews it is extremely easy to setup the wireless printing feature on this printer and the printer itself prints nicely even in draft mode. HOWEVER, this printer is a complete disaster from a user perspective. Unless you have an endless money supply and don't mind stock piling plenty of replacement cartridges.This printer is the last straw for me in purchasing HP Inkjet Printer products. This printer's design clearly shows the number one motivation of HP, revenue over customer satisfaction.There are two completely unacceptable functional designs in this printer.1. Each time you install a new inkjet cartridge the printer goes through a 'printer initializing' process. During this process the program sucks 10% of the remaining ink cartridges installed. So if you replace each of the four cartridges over a one week period without printing a single page each of the remaining cartridges will contain 30% less ink once the last cartridge is installed. This means that you basically have to replace all cartridges at the same time unless you don't mind wasting 30% of your ink.2. The MOST FRUSTRATING PART OF THIS PRINTER is the fact that you CANNOT PRINT unless all cartridges are full.So I am getting ready for a critical meeting in 1 hour, I need to print a multi-million dollar proposal for my top client for this meeting. I know I have plenty of black ink because I installed a new cartridge yesterday. I go to print this important document and the printer WILL NOT PRINT MY BLACK AND WHITE DOCUMENT BECAUSE THE CYAN INK was now out of ink! Now I know for a fact that this Cyan printer cartridge contained at least 10% ink when I installed the new black ink cartridge because a ran the printer report. So now I am panicking and grab another Cyan ink cartridge that I know contained 20% of ink remaining when I replaced it. It once again goes through it 'printer initializing' process and now it won't print my BLACK AND WHITE DOCUMENT because the yellow ink is now gone!!! Keep in mind the yellow ink had a little less than a 1/4 of its ink remaining before I replaced the Black ink cartridge. Now after replacing the Cyan cartridge now the yellow ink gone so I again replace it with a used cartridge that had about 1/4 remaining but after this initializing process now all color ink cartridges are completely empty. Keep in mind, during this time I haven't been able to PRINT a single document since replacing the Black cartridge the previous day. So now I am completely out of three ink cartridges all because I changed out three cartridges.So now I am so frustrated I want to throw the printer out my 10 story office window, if only the window opened. In a last ditch effort I call HP Support to ask how I can bypass the color cartridges to print my black and white document. I am told by support that the printer cannot print without the color cartridges. When I ask why I am told that it is due to the printer's high quality printing. So when I ask how in God's name does a yellow ink cartridge impact the quality of a black and white document, I get crickets chirping from the support person until he asks if I would like to speak with a supervisor. When I say yes, he places me on hold until the system hangs up on me 5 minutes later. I call back, now I immediately ask for a supervisor. The supervisor tells me that is the way the printer is designed. It uses color ink even in black and white documents to ensure 'quality' printing and says he will send me a link to contact the CEO with my comments.Moral of the story, NEVER buy a printer that 'requires' color cartridges to print black and white documents. There is only one reason that color ink is required to print black and white and it is to sell more ink cartridges. This printer is purposefully wasting color inks in order to force the buyer to replace the cartridges as much as possible. Until HP rewrites their printer software to eliminate this wasteful ink usage I think anyone that purchases any of their inkjet printers should have their head examined. By the way I worked for HP in their Enterprise Software division so I am not just some HP hater.

Title: I'm working
Review: The printer is more then I expected. Love it greatly and the quality is awesome. I'm so happy I choose this model and black is my favorite color  :-)

Title: Poor Quality
Review: The quality for scanning and copying are not very good. My previous unit was HP 7780 which was very difficult to install the software, but once installed worked great. Also I noticed any files I scanned in PDF were double the size wit the 8600 compared to the 7780. Even with all the settings set at best on the 8600 are not as good as the 7780 set midway.

Title: Lots of very useful functions! Poor software/some issues
Review: Useful functions in small office:+ rare automatic two sided scanning that also keeps pages in right order when done+ rare automatic 2 sided borderless brochure paper printing without leaving any white(recommend hp paper)+ Laser printer like speed+ Larger paper tray and scanner document feeder than most+ Ample copy settings including 2 sided and ID copy(prints 2 ID sides on one page)+ Can share usb drive like a NAS, works well with a few people.+ Can scan and print at the same time.+ XL ink is much cheaper per page than most and needs to be changed less. Also very easy to swap out without pull tabs.+ Printing will stop right before the ink runs out(less ruined prints)and prompt you to replace it before printing the next page.  No more worrying if a color is going to run out when batch printing. Also has the option to print in b/w if out of color.+ Jams a lot less than most. Handles 50 pound paper very well.Annoyances- Software is not laid out in a user friendly way. Many settings you need to dig for.- Having to dig through the menu to get to the black ink only setting. Considering the really low b/w cost per page its annoying its not on the first page. Not to hard but if you have a lot of users they may not use it.- Often feeds a blank page after a printout. Have no clue why, HP has yet to comment on this and how to fix it.- When printing a ink heavy document rarely runs out of a color at the end of the page ruining it but then prompts for the ink to be replaced before continuing.- Not a lot of room to get inside of the printer if needing to clear a jam or other problems. At least they have a light inside like a refrigerator!Overall a good choice for a small office just plan on spending the time to learn the features that are often hidden. Laser printer like costs and speed with benefit of borderless/photo inkjet printing. Really nice for batch printing/scanning with the added bonus of automatic 2 side functionality. Certainly a nice all in one printer that can do more than most.

Title: Very versatile printer but with a few concerns
Review: I bought this printer to replace my (now broken) networked Canon laser all-in-one. It is noisier than the Canon and the text quality is less sharp (which is typical of most ink jets). However, the included software is very user friendly and easy to install and set up. Plus, being able to fax, scan, and print double-sided color copies is, of course very useful.I connected this printer with an ethernet cable to my wireless router, and now can access it from any of my PCs or my MacBook Pro or MacMini computers. The installation software makes all these networked connections easily and correctly.I like all the diagnostic tests that are included (e.g. fax setup report, ink supply, fax history, etc.).I do have one issue with the AirPrint feature.  I bought and installed the optional second 250-page paper tray.  When I print from my iPad (4th generation), or my Samsung Galaxy S4, I noticed that it always pulls paper from tray #1.  However, when installing the second tray, HP says to make the default tray #2.  That way, you can put special paper (e.g. photo paper, envelopes, card stock, etc.) in tray #1. So I did the tray configuration as suggested.  When using AirPrint, the printer tried to pull media from tray #1 which contained 4X6 photo paper, so that of course triggered an error (and the printer refused to print some email from my iPad).I will try to figure out how to make AirPrint pull paper from tray #2.I must also mention ink consumption.  The latest Consumer Reports says that this printer is among the worst printers for non-printing ink consumption (i.e. ink used for printer head cleaning and other maintenance functions).  I think this excess consumption can be mitigated by (1) the large size of the ink cartridges and (2) leaving the printer turned on (in sleep mode) all the time.Lastly, I did try printing a few photos.  They turned out pretty good...Which is a great feature of this printer.  I do have a dedicated Canon Pixma Pro-100 photo printer for 'serious'  photo prints, but honestly, the photo prints from the OfficeJet 8600 are very acceptable.

Title: NO NO NO -- Don't buy this printer
Review: I bought this printer to replace a cheap HP all in one printer I have had for five years that has worked fantastically but was having issues due to age and use.  I wanted a more robust printer because I do a lot of printing.  This printer is a joke for the money.  It will not pull the paper through properly to get a straight scan. You have to use the glass tray.  The printing on some pages with lines is obvious that the paper wasn't pulled properly.  The paper tray is flimsy.  I can't get it to print the entire page (footer) without lying to it about the size of paper, whereas it printed fine before on my old cheap printer. I purchased it from Staples and since it has been three weeks, I can't return it so I am stuck with this junk.  I was planning to buy a HP all in one computer, but since I have seen the quality of the printer, I changed my mind and bought a Dell.  What has happened to HP???

Title: A great light home office use printer
Review: We purchased this printer to use in our home office for light duty printing (100 pages/month) and scanning and it has been rock solid as far as printers go.We love the wireless printing and scanning and even moreso, the touch screen on the printer that allows configuration and connection to our secure wireless network without having to run some crazy software on our computer that installs a dozen programs just so you can 'detect and configure' the printer.  The touch screen is amazingly intuitive for performing simple tasks like copying, scanning, and printing photos from an SD card.The auto document feeder was a big selling point for us on this model, but we were sorely disappointed at how poorly it keeps documents aligned; almost every scanned document is skewed a little bit.  Putting inward pressure on the document guides seemed to help about 90% of the time, but was is an unfortunate chore.  Additionally, we were a bit frustrated that the scanner bed cover is not double-hinged, so scanning thick material like a book is awkward and hard to keep square to the glass (it puts pressure on one side of the book, pushing it a bit).We were also a bit disappointed that the printer does not come with a manual feed tray for one-off printing or thicker materials.  This caused cardstock to jam around the main roller.Our last frustration point is with the output tray -- basic 8.5x11 paper needs the extension pulled out which is incredibly flimsy and has a gravity-assisted popup paper stop.  This stop prevents longer material from coming out of the printer, but was disabled by taping down the paper stop.

Title: Awesome printer
Review: Very sophisticated printer, wifi and ethernet connections very useful for LAN sharing and getting online info. Cool double sided printing and the inks are fantastic, laser like output.

Title: Good printing, disappointing scanning
Review: Prints great and is much quieter than an HP I bought several years ago. But the top scanner part will only pull a few pages through before it starts snagging. Have to scan one at a time on the glass to guarantee pages won't get mixed up.

Title: great copier....feeder doesn't always feed the paper straight so thing copy and scan crooked
Review: great copier....feeder doesn't always feed the paper straight so thing copy and scan crooked.You can email to this printer from anywhere and it will print.This e-print stays connected unlike the lower models I have purchased

Title: Very Nice!!!
Review: I had the HP Office Jet 6500 Wireless which broke via the black print head going out which is not replaceable.I replaced it with this printer and couldn't be happier.  Love the touch screen!  Love the large paper tray!  I only use it wirelessly, as I did with the old one, but this one was much easier to get set up wirelessly.  Love the newer 950/951 XL cartridges that hold more ink than the XL cartridges the other printer took (920 series).I'm very happy and highly recommend this All-In-One!BTW, this is based on me owning it since November of 2012.  Zero complaints so far and really love it.  Hopefully the print heads last longer than 2 years on this one with daily use, that only lasted 2 years on the other already  mentioned.

Title: 100% as described and reviewed
Review: After considerable review opted for this HP model having owned Epson, Canon and an earlier HP before. After a week it seems to perform as described. Fuss- free.

Title: Ink NIGHTMARE!
Review: We've had this printer for about a year and have liked it very much, up until now.  What changed?Ink.1).  It is impossible for this printer to print in black-ink-only, despite the fact that black-ink-only and high quality grayscale are options you can choose.  Apparently the printer draws ink from the color cartridges as well--with EVERY PRINT--for two reasons, given by an HP representative on their customer support webpage. The first reason is that the ink flow prevents the cartridge from plugging up.  The second reason is to provide a high-quality black print.  So, the entire time you're using it, you're using the much more expensive colored inks, whether you want to or not.  This is supposed to be one of the cheapest printers per page on the market.  Not sure if that's entirely true.2).  This printer WILL NOT PRINT when the color ink cartridges are empty.  WILL NOT.  In fact, if just ONE cartridge is empty you can't.  You can't just keep an empty color cartridge in there and print using just the black ink.  It won't let you.  Not until you replace the color cartridge.  And when does it warn you about this occurring?  WHEN it occurs.  No advanced warning that cartridges are running low.  So there you are, late on a Sunday night, you have a paper due in the morning and you CANNOT print it.  You're screwed.  Thanks, HP.Here's a link to the HP Customer support conversation that was most, hmm, helpful to me in understanding just how deep the crap is that I'm standing in and that HP dishes out.http://h30434.www3.hp.com/t5/Printer-All-in-One-Install-Setup-e-g-Windows-8/do-i-have-to-buy-color-ink-cartridges-HP-Officejet-Pro-8600/td-p/1706711

Title: The Best
Review: Oh, I just love this machine. I am able to get ride of four pieces of equipment, total declutter of the office. The printing is great but I am especially pleased with the faxing and the ability to connect to my phone and answering system with such ease. Great product!!

Title: Great Printer
Review: This is a good printer, fax, copier, and e-printer.  I have a laptop in my bedroom and the printer is in the frontroom and it prints fantastic

Title: excellent, as it was supposed to be
Review: Very high quality durable device, quality and speed is at a satisfying level, good life of Ink cartridge for a normal home use

Title: I got a faulty unit
Review: I've been using 6500 without any problem but right out of the box, the 8600 is jamming the paper, 4 pages in a row.HP never disappoints me but this time, whoa. I'm going to exchange it and see what happens. I'm very tech savvy so it's not like I don't know what I'm doing. Machines can be defective, period.

Title: HP Officejet Pro
Review: It's a great wireless all in one printer, it was a replacement for my Kodak, which I got tired of replacing printheads.

Title: For home office it's fine.
Review: the reason I gave it 3 stars is because it doesn't do what I personally wanted it to do.  I wanted it to print on 110# cardstock. That appears to be too hard for it.  It can print on 80# cardstock. HP had told me it could print on cardstock but the guy couldn't understand the difference between 80# and 110#.  To get it to print on 80# you have to change the printer settings to heavy paper setting.for other home office uses it does the job.  I've printed emails, address labels, conference badges, etc and have had no issues so far with those tasks.

Title: Use Mac? Do NOT buy HP
Review: I have used HP stuff for years, reliability has been good, quality satisfactory and easy to buy supplies.  However, I have two fully functional HP all-in-one printers that I can only print to because HP does not develop the drivers for new versions of the Mac operating system effectively eliminating much of the functionality of the printer.Regardless of the quality, reliability, etc., I no longer buy anything from HP.  If the company won't stand behind the products they sell, the hell with them.  (One cannot not help but think how horrified David Packard and William Hewlett would be by the way their company's fabulous reputation is being destroyed by present management.)

Title: Best wireless all in one I have used
Review: The printer exceeded my expectations in every way from ease of installation to readily finding supplies this printer has made my home office (not an official business) so much more productive. It sits in the corner and does its job. I can print from email or wherever I am and the print quality in "photo perfect".

Title: Perfect small office printer, fast and easy to use interface
Review: Exactly as advertised, Fantastic price, quick shipping, This printer is highly recommended, glad I purchased on Amazon, by far the lowest price on the internet for this printer.  As with all inkjets, the cartridge prices are very high

Title: Exceeds my expectations
Review: The HP Officejet Pro 8600 exceeds my expectations. It is a little larger than other printers I've had, so make sure it fits the space you have for it, but it has been performing admirably for me. I love the 2-sided printing, and speed of printing!

Title: Horrible, Horrible, Horrible
Review: My apologies to the seller for this bad review, but I regret spending my hard-earned money on this printer. I mostly bought it to scan, but the scanner only worked for a few months and has never worked again.  I've spent many, many hours on HP online support, etc., trying different things.  I even spoke to HP phone support and after 3 hours the tech said he was sorry, couldn't figure out the problem.  I was down to being able to only scan 5 pages in a row and now I cannot even scan one page without going in to the HP Scan Doctor program - which, interestingly enough - says there's nothing wrong with the scanner.  I've got this piece of equipment ready for the dumpster as soon as I budget for a new piece of equipment.  I've been an HP customer for decades and this is about the third printer in a row that did not work (yeah, I know, dumb, right?  Well, I have finally gotten the message:  no more HP products.

Title: HIGHLY RECOMMENDED !!!!!
Review: This printer is fast and efficient with more features than expected.Print quality is great and it is easy to send directly to e-mail.I purchased this printer to replace our old HP printer in my home office, mainly due to the fact that the old one was "Not Wireless". Before buying, I checked with Consumer Reports and found that this was the highest rated "ink jet" combo printer on their website. I found a back-to-school bundle special offered thru Wal-Mart, and with the Site-To-Store option, I picked up the printer in less than a week and saved quite a bit from the Consumer Reports approximate retail selling price. I really like the fact that the printer has automatic 2-sided printing, a separate 4x6 photo tray, is capable of e-print from my phone, document feeder and flat bed scanning/copying, and also individual ink cartridges. The 7520 does take a little time to set up, but will be well worth it.et-up for home use was a bit of a hassle until I decided to start over with the process. Apparently, I'd opened the fold-out control panel too far. Restowing it and reopening it 'fixed' the issue. Since then I've used some of the machine's capacity, including scanning, copying and printing regularly. Used the ePrint process once without a problem. Nice feature if you don't mind leaving your printer on fulltime. Similarly, you can subscribe to free services and receive regular faxes. Haven't had to replace any ink cartridges yet. A quick check says I'm about half full (some might say half empty 8^) on all 4 colors.

Title: Great reliable printer
Review: One of the best and most reliable printers I have wver owned and has fairly cheap ink. I am looking to buy another one.

Title: Great AIO Printer""
Review: " I just want to say that I am going thru a divorce and had to scan, print and fax more papers than I care to say.  It was cheaper for me to buy the machine than to go to kinkos and easier because I am ill with cancer.  I have had no problems at all after much use and the ink levels are still good, unlike previous HP printers.  I highly recommend this product to anyone looking for a good office all in one printer for everyday use!

Title: Buying the HP OfficeJet Pro Plus E-All-in-One printer was a good experience for me!
Review: So far I love it. It was easy to setup plugging it into my router. Now my wife's laptop uses it and my PC uses it and both were a snap to setup. It also prints almost as soon as I select a print job unlike my last All-In-One from HP. It is quiet and it is fast. I have also used the double sided copy and 20 some pages plus copied both front and back without a hitch. I have printed color also and it looks great. This is a powerhouse printer for a Mom & Pop office or for your home use. Medium to large offices should go with a much larger version I would think. So far I give this thing a 5 star rating. The one drawback I see is the paper tray. You cannot load glossy paper at the same time you load regular paper. You must load one type or the other and the same goes for envelopes. They have made that process very simple to do so for me that isn't really a drawback but for others it might be.

Title: Ok I guess
Review: Appeared to be an older model that sent with lots of nicks and scratches on the box. Works fine however. HP is an excellent brand

Title: Disconnects every 15 minutes
Review: The thing all these obviously bought-and-paid-for 5 star reviews refuse to tell you is this: Every 10 minutes this printer goes into sleep mode and, if you 'wake' it back up, it will no longer connect to your wireless router, forcing you to redo the entire wireless setup again to get it to connect. Previous HP models allowed you to disable this sleep feature, but this model only lets you extend the period to 15 minutes, and there's no sign that HP is going to fix this. It turns your otherwise fabulous wireless printer into a massive brick that only works when you connect directly. Don't even get me started on how awful trying to get the software installed was, or how it STILL refuses to work on one on my windows 7 laptops. The only solution is to either print constantly, or write a script that runs in the background of your PC that 'pings' your printer every few minutes, which significantly reduces the lifespan of your printer. Even giving it a static IP bound to it's MAC address in my wireless router settings doesn't fix the issue.I chose this printer because it has a good cost-per-page for black and white pages, but given all the headaches I've had thus far just trying to get it to print it all, HP has lost me as a customer. This is a gigantic piece of garbage and I hope I've saved at least 1 person the pain of having to deal with it.

Title: mediocre printer
Review: I love this printer scanner fax except for one thing - the software must consistently be re-booted as it fails to sustain memory with a computer. This can be very annoying if you do a lot of scanning.

Title: Constant paper jams
Review: Bought this machine to consolidate so we could print from all our devices in the house. After a year of working near flawlessly, the machine started jamming, with no serious paper jamming/crumpling  issues, just jamming mid-print. I have followed every troubleshooting step offered by HP. I have scoured the web in search of a solution. I am stuck essentially with a $200 all-in-one brick. HP screwed up their computer business and now it has done the same to its flagship printer business. I am done with HP. Do not waste your money on this piece of s***

Title: Work Horse
Review: Wonderful combination of the four necessary communication actions: copy, scan, print, fax. Printing on both side of the paper is great and automatic document feeder works great.

Title: color catridges needed to print black and white
Review: the officejet pro 8600 plus works well enough,BUT if your color cartridge set runs out of one color it becomes a real pain.I mostly print black and white and I am really angry that HP is so money hungry that I am forced to buy a new set of colors in order to continue to print B&W when ONE color has run out.If one of your colors runs out it forces you to push an ok to print B&W button EACH TIME ! and now it won't print at all until I replace the color !SHAME ON YOU HP !

Title: Terrible. Avoid at all costs.
Review: Since having purchased this item, I have had to reinstall it 6 times. It will work for a day or two, and then suddenly the printer will no longer interact with the computer. It has reached a point now where reinstalling will not resolve the problem. Am currently in the process of returning.Save your time, get another printer instead. I HAD to give this product a single star for Amazon to accept this review.

Title: Fantastic Printer for Home Office
Review: I bought this printer as I frequently work from home.  I needed to print several binders full of color information before a trade show, and also scan a bunch of other documents.  This printer has been great because it's super easy to set up, it prints quickly, the print quality is great for business printing (presentations, spreadsheets, etc), it prints double sided, and it scans double sided.Overall, this is the absolute best home office printer I have ever interacted with and it's surprising to me the quality you can get at home after using only industrial sized office machines for years.  If you need to have a regular printer for every day printing and the occasional large print job, this will be perfect for you.  My large color binders were done in no time last week and looked great, and I think my team was pretty happy with the results.  Also, the cost per page of ink is not too bad.I think this printer is not for you if you print very rarely (go with something cheaper and smaller) or if you have a mini print shop and are printing more than 200 pages daily...  Otherwise, this hits the sweet spot that most home office types and households will really appreciate.

Title: Envelope issues
Review: Jams printing multiple envelopes.Very limited envelope size selection & No custom envelope size option. So no mailmerge for Christmas cards, party invites...can't handle those odd envelope sizes.Photos printed better from my Canon.HP clearly has known about this envelope issue (it is all over the message boards) but has not come up with a solution. That tells me what I need to know about this company. The machine is marketed as a home office all in one machine but it doesn't do envelopes & HP not fixing driver to handle envelopes! This printer is still new but I've wasted well over $300 worth of time trying to print envelopes. I will be selling it second hand & shopping for something other than an HP.

Title: GREAT PRODUCT
Review: CAME HIGHLY RATED FROM AMAZON AND I AGREE WITH THAT RATING.LOVE EVERYTHING ABOU IT.BUY IT YOU WON'T BE DISAPPOINTED.BEST PRINTER PURCHASE .

Title: I've bought my last HP product.
Review: During initial installation this printer gave a leaky cartridge error and would NOT proceed.  I stayed on the phone with HP Support for 1 1/2 hours and couldn't clear the error.  They've got to send me a new print head but want to use Ground shipping which the rep said would take a week to reach me.  I need it Next Day Air but they want ME to pay $17 freight!  It's their product and was bad right out of the box.  Why can't they pay the $17?  I own a small company with a server and 8 Computers and 8 printers. Dell/Canon/Brother - Here I come.

Title: Does everything I need a printer to do.
Review: It does what I need a printer to do.  I found not all photo papers work well.  The one that it suggested works great.I have several grandchildren, therefore do use the photo feature quite a bit.  I like the wireless feature.  So farI nocomplaints.

Title: Very simple and very nice.
Review: So simple that even a grandpa can use it.  Grandma does too.  Printing is good and photos are very good.

Title: HP Officejet Pro 8600 Plus e-All-in-One is DEAD
Review: The first one 1 received for my office was DEAD ON ARRIVAL! The new one worked but, it eats pages if you try to fax or scan multiple pages from the top feeder. I also have one at home, it also eats pages when trying to fax or copy from the top feeder. It's now completely dead. I've had it for 1 year and 27 days with VERY little use. Tech support spent 35 minutes continually putting me on hold. When I asked to speak with a supervisor, I was put on hold again and the same person came back trying to disguise his voice- really? I called back the sales number and asked for tech support or some other help, was put on hold and the woman who initially answered came back trying to disguise her voice! I can't fathom how this is HP's idea of 'customer service'. I will never buy another product from this company, they have raised the bar for garbage products and service.

Title: It's everything it was supposed to be
Review: The machine works very well for my purposes.I would say that it is well built and easy to set up.

Title: Broke 4 months out of warranty
Review: 4 months after the warranty ended the printer's display stopped working (all white), which rendered its scanning capabilities useless. A quick google search shows is not at all an unusual problem with this model. HP offered to replace it for 187$, which basically means this was the last HP printer I bought.

Title: GREAT PRINTER
Review: VERY NICE PRINTER, EASY TO SET UP WIRELESS. COPY VERY GOOD. HAVE ONE AT WORK ALSO GETS USED ALOT, NO TROUBLE SO FAR.

Title: love love love
Review: this was a great purchase I use one at home and one at the office.  I have had a lot of printers and this is by far my favorite.

Title: Don't waste your time!
Review: I've used this for about a year and I'm so irritated by this product, I will NEVER buy another HP printer again.  You cannot print ANYTHING if any of the print cartridges are empty!  I've attempted to print in draft mode, black only and I STILL can't print!  The manual has a section for 'how to print with one or more depleted ink cartridges' and all it says is that you must replace them!  Yes, the ink consumption is not bad, probably slightly better than most other printers, but if you are caught on a saturday night and want to print out those movie tickets you purchased online, but don't have a spare yellow lying around, you can't print them!The scanner is set to the lowest resolution possible, and it STILL takes 6 minutes to scan 5 pages! (one side only!)  This is simply NOT acceptable!  The auto feed is fairly limited in the number of pages that can be scanned at one time.  If you have more than 6-8 pages, the document feeder has a tendency to skew the pages and rip the edges as they are fed through.  That's a problem for me.  If I'm taking the (extremely) long time to scan a document, its probably important to me and I don't want it shredded by the time its finished.My boss thought he was doing me a favor when he picked up a newer version of this model for me to use at work.  He was so excited about it, I didn't have the heart to tell him that he'd wasted the money.  These are absolute junk!!  The print quality is standard; not great but not bad either.  The scanning is mediocre for quality and horrible for the time investment.  The ePrint feature is nice when you want to print from your mobile device; however, its not worth the aggravation with the other problems.

Title: Great, but running into some issues.
Review: Overall, I love this printer - it was perfect for me because I had zero room for it on my desk and needed a wireless solution.  I have had the printer for probably a month or so now, maybe 6 weeks and today had my first issue.  Out of nowhere, all the lights on the front panel began flashing (wasn't trying to print anything), and asked for a reboot.  Rebooting just brought me back to the flashing lights, rinse and repeat.  Finally looked for solutions online - found something saying it should be plugged into a wall outlet, not a power strip.  Maybe I missed this in the install instructions, but for whatever reason, that solved the issue.  Hopefully it stays that way, because otherwise, this is a nice little printer.

Title: The hp Pro 8600 Plus; It's my choice
Review: I have owned 6 or 7 hp printers, this one is the best with a large paper tray, consumes less ink is multi function i.e., Fax, email...

Title: peggy" was finally helpful"
Review: This is a pretty good machine WHEN it WORKS, because, theoretically, it is quick, and customizable.Unfortunately, it is plagued with bugs and defects, and doesn't work. Others seemed to have had similar experiences...This (nearly $200) machine died after 6 weeks of use. First the phantom paper jam that others talk about. Then, the real paper jam. Then, after enough fiddling with the paper rollers, it started making noise like a freight train in my printer, with rasping, grating, sounds like the teeth on the gears were grinding off!! (They probably were).Then, a whole host of error messages followed.After speaking with 'Peggy' of technical support, who ran me through a redundant set of troubleshooting steps ( so he could document a reason why he was eventually going to replace my printer), and an hour-and-a-half on the phone, some of it while waiting for the HP firmware upgrade, and finally having him listen over the phone to the awful noises coming out of the machine, he told me I would need a replacement.(Duh!!)Then, he told me it would be 11 days until one arrived. Now, mind you, I have a home office, and have no printer/fax/capable machine (stupid me! I should always have a spare in the closet), and that if I had bought the (ridiculously priced) special, 'extended' warranty (note that I am still in the regular warranty period), then it could be expedited-shipped overnight at no cost. But the warranty would have cost me over 70 bucks. So, in order to get the new pone, I had to shell out $37 for overnight delivery. I have 15 days for them to receive (not from when I send it) the old one, or I also get charged for the new machine, even if the return shipping only pays for ground delivery.HP 'support'?If I didn't already have the ink for this machine, I would buy a different brand.Don't bother with this machine!!!

Title: Finally a printer that works with all things Apple!
Review: Buy it, it simply works! And the iOS app is great... You can scan, fax etc. from your iPad or phone..

Title: Run Everybody!!!!
Review: This particular printer has a real flaw that we tried to work around to little avail. It periodically insists on an alignment procedure and then proceeds into an endless stream of error messages. These include, but are not limited to, clearing a phantom paper jam, having a bad print head, bad cartridges, jammed head travel path and on. It's like being on a Punked episode but no one shows up at the end.I have sifted through a raft of people with the same problem in the support groups and a host of HP "Experts"  that want kudos for a list of silly procedures that you have tried endlessly or you wouldn't be there in the first place! In the end we will call Tech Support ,read that as "Peggy" and find a box of appropriate size to bury the beast.

Title: Could have been great
Review: The HP OfficeJet Pro 8600 Plus is easy to install in any typical configuration (wired network, wireless network, or USB). The printer sips ink and prints quickly, and I am well pleased with both text and graphics. Print cartridges are fairly priced, and the cost-per-page is comparatively low.I have encountered three issues, however, which detract significantly from my initially positive opinion of the printer:* I have *never* had a problem with paper jams. However, my unit typically has problems picking up photo paper or card stock (both HP-brand, no less). I would think twice about buying this model if you intend to print pictures or homemade greeting cards.* Envelope printing is a train wreck. Just forget it. Even standard #10 business envelopes require such a wide left margin that the printed envelope looks terrible. HP needs to improve its drivers, but that will likely never happen, of course. My solution? I have to keep an old HP DeskJet 6940 connected to use as a dedicated envelope printer. Thanks so much, HP.* If you want to use the printer with Linux, good luck. I have had little success, even with the latest hplip download. It's fine for printing standard 8.5 x 11 pages. Forget scanning, and scan-to-computer isn't even an option. Why do printer manufacturers still have lousy Linux support for these all-in-one printers? How hard can it be? Support your products!

Title: DON'T DO IT! CONSIDER YOURSELF WARNED...
Review: We've literally been through 3 of these printers. Bought the initial one at Fry's, immediately it did not work. We returned it and got another one. It worked for a few days, then magically, the yellow cartridge ran out! Within a week! We replaced the ink and it happened again within days. We called HP, they sent us a replacement print head. After installing it, the same problem kept occurring. They then sent us a whole new unit (but would not, of course, reimburse the cost of the many ink cartridges we had gone through). New unit arrived, worked for a little while, then ink began to magically run out again (only the yellow). At this point, we would replace the ink, then we finally gave up on the printer and only used it for black/white copying and document printing. A year after having the new unit with minimal usage, we tried to print a picture and magically, the yellow cartridge was once again empty! Even though we hadn't used it. We are now done with HP products forever. This has been a nightmare. 3 printers in a row of the same make/model that don't work. Obviously, there are some serious issues with this model. If you actually own one that works, consider yourself one of the lucky!

Title: So disappointed
Review: I purchased this from Costco this weekend (not Amazon).I'm so disappointed. I have an Etsy shop that I need clear vibrant prints for. I could never sell what comes out of this printer. The colors are very flat/muted/not crisp. I would not even use this for fliers as it is not a professional quality. If HP is going to have a Office printer with color you'd think they would make one that prints professional quality. The B&W printer prints a crisper black. And forget printing photos!!! I tried adjusting the colors in my graphics, I tried adjusting the settings (I even printed on 'best' quality. with his resolution).I gave 2 stars instead of 1 because it is fast and didn't have problems feeding the photo paper.

Title: Will not print custom size paper
Review: This printer and apparently other newer HP printers only allow you to print preset sizes. You can create your own custom size within Word for Mac for instance but the HP print dialog box greys out the custom sizes and does not allow you to print them.  I spent 4 hours looking in HPs forums for an answer then spent an hour on the phone with HP and never got a solution. I later found posts from HP employees saying their printers don't support custom sizes.  What a waste of time.
