Review: We process a lot of paperwork and use these printers to handle it. We use these printers for all of our remote offices that need a solid all-in-one solution. When ever we need a new printer, these are what we buy.

Title: Printer a little problematic
Review: The seller delivered very quickly, good service.This printer would have got 5 stars but for a big problem.When it goes into energy saving mode it drops the network connection and a reboot of my computer is necessaryafter which it works OK until the next time. I have a lot of knowledge of routers and networking but this one hascaused me a lot of hassle. The whole point of wireless printing is lost with this. Having checked the web I have seenwhere this seems to be a problem between HP and MS Windows. Computer beginners wouldn't have a chance withthis one. HP needs to get this problem sorted out.

Title: Great!
Review: Work efficiently! Much better than my old printer, print out faster, clearer, more functions to connect your phone and fax

Title: Top Notch Quality and Convenience
Review: Everything on this printer works great.It prints great quality images. I love being able to print from anywhere.The touch display is great and intuitive. I have had it for 3 months and would buy it again without question.

Title: Nice Printing & Features -- but do they work?
Review: I quite like the print quality and speed; however, if you are operating a Mac using Mountain Lion operating system you will work hard to keep from taking a baseball bat to this printer especially when you are trying to scan.  It is flaky as can be.  About a third of the time it doesn't work on wifi -- but it is a nice feature thought.  Your level of productivity is probably higher if you went to a shop to scan in your documents.  Perhaps you should have an Epson scanner on the side.  But, then, why buy this?  I suggest you look elsewhere -- seriously.  I've had a lot of HP failures and wish that Apple would get back into printers or I'll move over to another brand.....Added a tad later.  I actually don't know if any manufacturer has a better printer.  They may all be difficult with Apple Macs.

Title: Great Printer
Review: The print quality is quite superior. We are perhaps most pleased with the speed of printing. The XL cartridges provide very long service life. Just be sure to use the cartridges packed with the printer for initial setup; it is essential.

Title: Wireless printer
Review: I bought this printer because of excellent review in Consumer Reports and I wanted a wireless printer so ipad, and other laptaps would have printing capability.  I performs well--I have used the fax, scan and copy functions.  Faxing seems slow as the pages have to scan in and their are pauses between sheets but it does work well.  However, on the downside it took 10 hours to install this machine.  We could not get the wireless hookup to work.  We called the chat helpdesk--agent in India--after 2 1/2 hours, he had totally wasted my time.  I called and spoke to an agent in the Phillippines--much more knowledgeable who also took 2 1/2 hours and finally  connected the machine via an ethernet cable and it worked.  Why it took 5 hours to get to this & why it could not be connected wireless still remains a mystery.  Now that it is working, we like the machine.  We do suggest not using agents in India.

Title: Pain to print envelopes
Review: I've had this printer for about 3 months now in my small business office with daily use, printing maybe 20-50 sheets per day.I am satisfied except for one thing, printing envelopes or any time you need to change paper types.  You have to slide out the paper tray in the front and remove all existing paper, then replace it with whatever you're printing on, then do the reverse to switch back to copy paper.  This may not sound like much but to print one envelope it creates quite the hassle instead of allowing you to place the envelope on top of the stack of copy paper (like the previous HP model I owned), or having a separate slot for envelope feeding.  Like most printers, it gets a little finicky when trying to print on one single sheet in the feeder tray, it takes a few trys to get it to grab the paper/envelope.

Title: Good value
Review: I have had this printer for about a month and I have been pleased thus far. I use the scanning function on a daily basis. It is not as fast as a dedicated scanner but it is still efficient (don't expect it to scan 20 pages in a minute) The auto feed function allows you to do other things while the scanning is taking place. The set up process was user friendly. The main negative is the price of the ink.

Title: Not happy with this printer!
Review: I bought this multifunction printer a year ago.  It works fine for printing in black and white and color.  I have only recently begun using it for scanning and trying to print photos.  Before using this printer while I had an older HP multifunction machine, I would typically scan documents in the range of 25-50 pages, save them as PDFs, and email them without a problem.  With this printer, when I scan the documents the PDF files that are created are so huge that they are unable to be emailed due to their size.  I spoke with HP customer service and was given no explanation or help, even when trying to tell them my old HP machines didn't have this problem.  Documents scanned in color, by the way, are a fraction of the size of black and white scans and can be emailed easily.  Scanning with this machine is *extremely* slow.  Also, in regard to trying to print photos on photo paper, forget it.  The paper feed will not pick up photo paper.  I have tried HP photo paper and other brands to no avail.  This will be the last HP machine I ever purchase.

Title: Great all in one-BUT
Review: I love that this printer is wireless. I trust hp printers and so far this printer is no exception EXCEPT its scanner. If you just want to copy and scan thing and dont care about the quality, then no problems. BUT if you are serious about what you scan and want control over the scans, you need a dedicated scanner. I have a canon scanner for serious scanning.  I cannot speak about the fax function since i dont use it. My one irritation is you have to push the paper output tray closed to access the paper tray when empty or want to change paper type. It also doesnt like heavy weight paper.

Title: HP updates tell U buy Ink or bad cartridge WHEN INK at 45%
Review: NONE - HP is ripping off consumers on purpose with the full knowledge of the HP executives!NEVER EVER BUY an HP Home Printer, everyone I have had recently in the last 3 years or so have been this exact same way- I was stupid to give HP a try againGarbage Printers designed to steal your moneyDoes not work correctly 75% of Time, this Printer will connect to HP for Updates, as soon as the updates are done the printer will tell you the cartridges are empty or defective etc. regardless of how much ink ! Criminal Activity by HP to get you to buy more super expensive cartridges which print 150 pages or less (on default) Default ink settings are NOT on Economy, again to rip you off forcing you to buy more ink, if you change default to economy ink printing it will automatically revert to INK Drink settings Again to force you to buy more ink! So unless you change the settings to economy or draft EACH time you print you will run out of ink in like 150 pages! HP Sends Criminal updates to your Printer tell U Buy Cartridges! Cartridges are very very expensive....These problems were corrected by me when I uninstalled all the bloat ware HP software, BUT only AFTER I uninstalled and used generic drivers instead AND BLOCKED the Printer from Communicating with HP ! After that my 45% full ink cartridges worked fine until they were dry! HP executives and the people who wrote the software designed to dupe and rip off consumers forcing them to buy expensive ink when they did not really need it should be put in Jail for the rest of their lives!

Title: Great quality & speed for the price
Review: Easy to install, intuitive operation and good picture prinitng quality. Very satisfied with the quality and speed for the price I paid.

Title: Useless as a scanner
Review: I bought the HP Officejet Pro 8600 Premium (the same as the 8600 but with two paper trays)because it had an automated document feeder that could hold 50 pages.  I was using a Fujitsu Scan Snap 1500, which holds less than 20 pages, and was hoping to reduce scanning time. I also thought I could save money buying an all-in-one machine.  Big mistake. This scanner is EXTREMELY slow.  The product specs say it scans at 'up to 11 ppm.'  That is only true if you scan at 75 dpi in black and white, which leaves you with a scan that is barely legible even when scanning simple black and white typed pages.  If you scan at 200 dpi - which is ok quality, but not great - you get 3 pages per minute!  If you want to scan at a higher quality dpi, the document feeder can not be used.  Instead, you have to manually place each page on the glass, go through the cumbersome scan process with every single page.  For comparison, my Fujitsu scans 20 ppm at 600 dpi.  If you are looking for a scanner, just buy the Fujitsu and buy a separate printer!  If you do decide to buy this printer, note the 14 day return policy and test it out the day you get it or you will be stuck with it!

Title: Easy set up
Review: Out of the box, connected and functioning in no time at all. If I can do it anybody can.Printer is fast and great print quality.

Title: Great print quality and speed
Review: I replaced another HP printer with this one, and so far, love it.  The only negative is the size; quite large.

Title: very useful
Review: This was a breeze to set up and use.  Scanning/copying is very easy and pages look great.Here are your 3 words.

Title: Works Great
Review: This printer works great. I can now copy and scan as well as print plus do it from anywhere. It would be hard to find a better device.

Title: Very good!
Review: Exceeds my expectations in all ways. Great quality, great functionality, VERY simple to set up, connect to multiple computers, remote printing, sending/receiving, everything. Also, goes to sleep mode automaticaly to save power  and life.  HP has a winner here.

Title: CARD STOCK?  HOW ABOUT NO.
Review: This seems to be a very nice printer. IT WILL NOT, HOWEVER, PICK UP CARD STOCK.I did not expect card stock to work in 'tray 2' as it is labeled 'plain paper only.' Unfortunately, it will not pick up card stock from tray one either. I was able to pull out tray one, look way in the back, and sort of feed the card stock into the little wheel thingies that pull on the paper. Timing was a bit of an issue, as was getting the paper in straight, but I am sort of good like that.

Title: HP Officejet Pro 8600 Plus
Review: This printer was very easy to set up. Between my wife and kids we have 5 computers that we can now print from anywhere ( work, different rooms in the house, and from the neighbors house).  Yes the clarity of pictures are great. Print speed is great and this version 'Plus'  has a larger paper tray and digital screen, which makes it more comfortable to use.  The only bad thing is the price for the ink!!!

Title: Outstanding HP product
Review: PROS:We run a small business and I am also the department head of a government agency.  I handle all the IT for both our business and my government agency.  I tried several printers, and recently read the CNET reviews about the HP OfficeJet Pro 8600.  This model comes in three versions, the 8600, 8600 Plus and 8600 Premium.  I went with the premium as it best fit our needs.  It works great.  It was an cinch to set up.  It took me longer to unwrap the printer from the packaging then to actually set it up on wifi.  The enclosed CD gives you the drivers that I had to install on our Macs OS 10.7 and 10.8 and our Windows 7 Pro computers.  The CD install ran smooth and I completed the first install in about 10 mintues with the remaining installs taking no more than 5 mintues.  You can also obtain the HP 8600 drivers from hp.com/support.I highly recommend this all-in-once device.  It's own web access is especially nice and the applications that HP added to this device is a techy fun, but also great for beginners.The touch screen menu display is vividly clear, easy to understand and easy to read, (even without reading glasses).  I usually read the entire manual on every item I purchase, but I found the 8600 Plus so easy to operate that I didn't read the manual to perform the set up operations.  It also helps that HP programmed into the 8600  complete step-by-step instructional video to help you set up the printer.  As soon as you plug it in and turn it on, you get instant help.If you need a fast printing, high quality device that is easy to set up and operate, this is your device.  This device is superb for personal use, in home office use or small business use.CONS:The only con I have to report is the 8600 takes up a lot of space.  If you are short on space to put your printer, this is not the device you want.  It will take up the entire shelf of most medium to large computer equipment cabinets.  It requires a space at least 18' wide and 12' long.  The 8600 stands a little over 12' high with the extended ADF on top.  That's the only CON I have to report.

Title: Finally, a great All in One printer
Review: I have been through a Dell, Canon and a Lexmark and I came back to the HP. I love the the legal size glass and the most important thing is use the right paper for the right job. Also, get an upgraded printer cable for faster transfer rate.

Title: Boooooooo!
Review: It is difficult for me to get to this review for all of the 'paper jam' edits......pay a monk to copy this for you as it may be faster! HP....hope you are listening!

Title: One for all and all in one
Review: A fast printer that does everything I need it to do.  Easy to set up and so versatile.  I plan on getting a second one.

Title: Inkjet and good? YES!
Review: I for one would never have thought it possible that I would write a positive five star review about any inkjet printer. Probably the only two printers I have owned in my lifetime that I could recommend with 5 stars was the Panasonic 1080i dot matrix, which I used with my Commodore 64, and my HP LaserJet P2015dn. What do I like about this printer?Pros:1) Very low ink usage. I am very surprised on how frugal it is with ink. Yes, the cartridges are expensive, but for an inkjet printer, they last far longer than any inkjet I have ever had before. This is without doubt the main attraction of this printer.2) The wireless setup is far easier than anything I have ever experienced before. The printer has a very nice touch pad screen that walks you through the process painlessly. You need absolutely no technical expertise to set it up.3) The software is great. What I need is a good OCR system to scan in pages of books I've read. The included OCR software is very good. I scan to .rtf format, crop to what I need, and paste my completed text into WordPad. I had a problem with Word because sometimes it would create a two column document when I didn't want it to. WordPad didn't allow the formatting for two columns, and so that solved my issue. It is very rarely that I need to correct the spelling due to poor OCR.4) The touch pad on the printer is one of its nicest features. Perform functions like scanning or copying or checking ink levels with ease.5) I do mostly duplex printing of brochures and booklets. Probably I've made 150 sixteen page booklets, and 300 tri-fold brochures. Both have a mix of color pictures and black text. I'm using 28 lb. paper and have never had a jam or problem so far. I'm on my 3rd ream of paper, and have replaced all the cartridges once. This may sound bad, but it's way better than I've experienced in the past. If I need to copy anything, it takes about 30 seconds for the first page.6) Usually this doesn't matter to me, but I like how it looks. (I'm beginning to feel like a HP salesman.)Cons:1) It's large. better check the dimensions of your printer space before getting it. Fairly tall as well.2) No third party cartridges available. Usually I order refilled cartridges. I tried this, and to my disappointment none are available. I'm sure HP is doing all they can to keep the ink purchases for themselves. That's the real problem with companies these days, they're so profit driven that customers are treated like lemmings.3) The printer is always asking me if I want to update the software? I don't, and wish it would quit asking.4) We don't have a landline, so I don't use the fax. Not really a con.All in all, I highly recommend this printer.

Title: Great Product...worth every penny!
Review: We love this item.  It's does everything and than some.  My son loves the Disney app and the whole family enjoys the daily crossword puzzle app as well.  I would recommend this product in a hearbeat!

Title: No problems and great product
Review: This is the fourth HP multifunction all-in-one printer I've bought over the past few years, including the 6500A, L7780, and 8500.  All of them are still in service and I have never had a problem with any of them.  I am not disappointed by this latest model.  The printer seems rugged enough and well-designed.  I like the fact that the power cord plugs directly into the printer without a power brick.  The print quality and speed seem great.Set up couldn't be easier.  I connected it to our wired Ethernet network, turned it on, and followed the on-screen instructions that are shown through animation.  I think some people complaining about the printer not functioning the way they want may be taking shortcuts during the setup process.  (I have not tried the Wifi setup, as I don't need it.)I can easily access all the features of this device through other PCs and devices on our local network, and can easily print directly from my iPhone and iPad!  The printer actually automatically shows up as a printer on these devices.  Using the hp e-print feature (where you assign an e-mail address to the printer), you can print anything to the printer by e-mailing it.  You can also control exactly who is allowed to e-mail print jobs to the printer.  I recommend restricting it so you won't have to worry about the printer getting a lot of spam mail that could cost you a lot in ink and paper.If I run into any problems with this device, I'll update my review.  So far, it is meeting my expectations.

Title: What ever happened to this great Company?
Review: Had it for a couple of months and the doc feeder just failed to pull paper through, just like my prior 8500 model.  Also began to show a vertical line through any scanned doc.  Did not use much so really no excuse for these problems.  It used to be I would consider nothing but HP printers, now I almost immediately dismiss!

Title: This seller is processing mail in rebates prior to selling product
Review: Excellent product BUT when I turned in the mail in rebate, HP rejected the claim because someone else had previously claimed it. HP accepts it is some kind of forgery because they ask for the original UPC code to be sent in which I did with my claim. So, this seller has allowed someone to submit and claim the mail in rebate before selling the product. BEWARE !!!!!!!!!!!!!!

Title: Terrific printer with Windows 8
Review: I just picked up this printer at a local warehouse store (sorry, but at the time they beat Amazon's price by $25), and I'm a big fan.  One of the best things about HP is that they were compatible with Windows 8 from day one and even had an app in the Windows store to access the scan feature for both documents and photos.  I absolutely loved the fact that it was not necessary to install separate drivers, which made printing from my wife's Surface tablet equally easy.The print quality is solid and it's extremely fast (as fast as the old Canon 4150 laser printer it replaced.)  The large-capacity print cartridges are a boon and I doubt that I'll need to replace them for literally a year or more due to the moderate use my family gets from the printer.  It really is a solid unit and quite possibly the best printer I've purchased thus far.

Title: Commercial all in one" printer."
Review: Outstanding piece of equipment. Very advanced for a end user/retail product. Except for the 'built in' scam of ink & paper usage; which in order to stop; just don't 'opt in' for e-commerce auto receive feature. Otherwise, a very nice unit.

Title: So far so good
Review: We set this all in one printer up in our office last week. So far so good. It was easy to set up and the wireless connection to 2 computers works great. I have yet to try all of the features but if the set up was easy I'm sure the rest is also user freindly. Quick to print pages and quiet.

Title: Good solid multi-function device
Review: Device was very easy to set up with little or no issues. The printing is clear, crisp, and the printer is quick to get started. I set it us with my MAC and have a wireless connection with no issues. i believe HP has a very good product on its hands.

Title: Excellent printer
Review: Excellent printer. I wish I purchased it a while ago if I knew it was this easy to use and print quality.

Title: Boat Anchor
Review: I am a loyal HP customer with nine HP printers and five HP desktops.  I like the HP OfficeJet Pro 8600 hardware and feature set quite a bit and its price is very reasonable.  However, this product is unreliable.  This particular printer just stops printing and nothing short of uninstalling/reinstalling the HP software package fixes the problem.  The HP printer diagnostic utilities are of no help.  The entire process is time consuming and happens, so far, about every two weeks.  Today, I changed the network connection to wired from wireless to see if that would be more reliable.HP needs to figure out how to engineer good software.  Printing shouldn't be this hard.

Title: Huge printer disappointment
Review: Do not buy this printer, it has been a huge disappointment from the beginning.  I was looking for a simple, cheap print, copy, scan device.  I have been irritated with this machine from the beginning, for the following:1. Start-up is too long and quite noisy.2. Print latency is longer than described, not a deal breaker, but annoying when combined with other annoyances.3. Inks run out too quickly and you cannot select a black only print mode.4. Color inks are too expensive.For a company that is supposed to dominate the printer business, this was a huge disappointment, they should be able to do better.At first I thought that I had a lemon, bet then I kept running into more disturbing features.  This is disappointing by design.My advice is to look elsewhere.

Title: Super slow scan
Review: I can't stand the scan speed on this printer.  To scan a batch of 30 pages, you will need to break them into small batch of 10 and it will take at least 10 to 15 minutes.  It is a painful painful process.  It is not for 'office' environment.

Title: Good printer, some bad software
Review: I have an older version from 2010.  The printing has worked fine with over 2 years of hard use but when using it in wireless mode large scan jobs often fail half way through.  Scans work fine when connected by usb, and all other wireless features work fine.  I have spent many hours with cusomer service and they can't figure it out.  Maybe I am the only one with this problem.Prints are good quality, fast enough for home use.

Title: Awesome Printer!
Review: Overview:I got this to replace my cheap $100 brother laser printer and cheapo lexmark all-in-one.  I couldn't be happier with this printer.  It prints extremely fast... faster than my old laser printer!  Also being able to scan directly to a network drive, computer, or send it to e-mail is a great feature to have.  All in all this printer really does it all.  I'm surprised that it is currently only at 3.5 stars because to me this is the best most fully featured printer I've ever owned.  Before buying this I tested out many printers at Best Buy and looked up a lot of reviews on Amazon.  This printer just stood out amongst the rest of them with all the features it has.Pros:- iOS compatibility- Scan to network drive- Scan to e-mail- Fast sheet feeder for scanning- very fast!- small office workhorse- network printing, no fuss software setupCons:- proto printing isn't the best but that's not really what this printer is for...- beware on windows to only enable ink level warnings during print otherwise the software may be a resource hog...Conclusion:This is by far the best printer I've ever owned.  It does everything I need it to do and does it well.  There is no comparison between this printer and the entry level printers on the market.  You could easily spend more on a high end business printer but at the price point, I don't think you can beat this printer.

Title: Love It
Review: First, this is the husband writing and I am a geek. I bought this All-in-one because my wife found our existing scanner and fax set up too difficult for her to use. The 8600 Plus is mind-numbingly simple to use. Insert papers in document feeder, follow instructions on screen. As to the set up, I had read the reviews saying that it was difficult. I would say the set up of the product was VERY simple, with one exception. I did not need any wires (other than the plug) to get the printer and scanner working. My wife could have set this up herself with one exception, the scan to network folder. I actually had to used the included software from my desktop to set up the network folder (on a WIFI enabled NAS). Other than that, all setup was done by following the prompts on the all-in-one's front screen. As an aside, although I bought this for my wife, I have literally scanned hundreds of pages already, emptying my file cabinet of old paper records. This thing works very, very well. I was a bit annoyed that my wife wanted me to replace a perfectly good scanner and printer with something 'easier', but I am now sold. It is fast, accurate and simple to use.

Title: Do Not Trust HP Warrantee
Review: I bought an HP All In One Printer on June 23, 2012.  It is now defective.  HP will only send me a Refurbished unit under warrantee, which amounts to a used unit.  HP warrantee's are worthless, dont trust HP.  I am very disappointed and sorry that I wasted my $350.00 on this printer.Pastor Walter Huyck

Title: Easy to Set Up
Review: I just bought the HP Officejet Pro Plus 8600 to replace a HP Officejet 6210 which I have used heavily since 2004. I bought a 6210 back then for me and one for my wife. Hers still works fine after eight years. These things are workhorses. I used a non-HP print cartridge in mine that exploded, causing the paper to stick and the printer to jam. It was a big mess inside and I decided it was time to consider buying a new printer instead of cleaning up the mess.  I felt guilty given what a reliable printer the 6210 had been.Based on Amazon reviews, which I always check and value, I would never have gone with an HP.  However, I asked my computer guru what he would pick and he strongly recommended the 8600. Based on his staunch support and my prior experience with HP printers, I went with the HP.My daughter also has an HP C3100 purchased in 2006, which she has never had trouble with. She told me the other day she lets other students print on her HP when theirs break down.While my prior experience was good in terms of basic printing and reliability, I always felt the HP software was a bit difficult. The scanning process was always a pain, for example.I just finished setting up the 8600. It was a breeze. The way it's packed and the way the instructions are set up it was a pleasure. Within an hour it was all set up and I had sent a fax, scanned a document, copied a document (in color) and printed a document - all via a wireless connection that took two minutes to set up.The print speed, scan speed and fax speed are lightning fast.The old problem of difficult software no longer exists. The software on the PC is easy to use and the new control panel on the printer is like the menu on a smart phone - very easy to navigate and use.The WebPrint feature is also easy to use. Anything you can email to your personal  @hpeprint.com address can print. So devices that don't have easy print solutions - phones, tablets - now do.Time will tell how reliable the printer is, how economical it is and if it will be a reliable workhorse like its predecessors. But the first hour, which I always dread, was a pleasure.

Title: Great printer
Review: Printer works great.  Printing pictures is fast and the finished printed pictures looks flawless.  Keyboard is easy to use.  No complaints

Title: Troubles
Review: We've spent hours with tech support over the months we've owned this.  It just does not print directly to email or iPhoto although we're sure we've set it up correctly.  When we print out on photo paper, we get a horizontal line sometimes.  It's a machine I use for faxing and copying but the rest is a real challenge and I am deprived of some of the features I need.

Title: Good printer
Review: I would like to recommend this printer to everyone who is looking for a HP printer. The price is reasonable and the product is good.

Title: Thus far, it is great
Review: Pros:  Prints fast, much faster than my former HP Color Laser printer.  Prints clear.  The price was exceptional.  The printer itself looks really nice.Cons:  Since it is an HP, I expect that when Windows 9 comes along, the printer will turn into a boat anchor, like my Color Laser printer did.  HP's support for new operating systems has been utter crap, thus far in my experiences with them.  The printer is also a bit loud, but I can totally live with that.

Title: Nightmare
Review: What? Isn't the seller an official HP seller? How come it didn't come with USB connection? There were a printer, a power line, a fax line and guide sheets. And even more horrible thing for now is that test printing (without connecting to my laptop) and any sort of printing outcomes show nothing on paper. It clearly seems it's broken or so. Gosh. What should I do?

Title: Beyond Happy!
Review: I spent a good amount of time researching printers.  Even with the best research you still never know what your going to get until you actually get it and start using it.I must say, this printer is worth every penny!  The speed at which it prints is mind blowing!  the clarity of the pictures rivals any drug store print!  We have three kids so we found ourselves going to the local big box or drugstore for photos, we will no longer be doing that!I would absolutely recommend this printer to everyone I know!

Title: Best Printer I Have Purchased!
Review: I have bought several printers over the years and this just works.  Plus, it is a workhorse.  I did all the requisite research and found this to be better than most reviews.  Perhaps I got the best one, but I doubt it.  Solid HP product.

Title: Would not feed paper. Returned it
Review: I could never get this printer to feed paper correctly. I tried everything from bargain basement to premium paper with no luck. I tried all the fixes or adjustments I could find on the internet. Finally gave up and returned it.

Title: Poor scan quality and HUGE file size.
Review: I needed an all-in-one unit for my home office. I went to my local best buy and I talked to an HP rep.  I explained to him my needs and wants and he recommended the HP Officejet 8600 PRO. The unit is very acceptable except when using the scan feature. My scans had "OK" quality... at best, and the size of the files were HUGE!  I talked to HP tech support in another country and tried desperately to change the settings to accommodate an adequate quality and size of scan without any success. I am very disappointed with the level tech support, customer service and product quality. When I talked to the HP rep at Best Buy I told him I was willing to spend $500 for a quality unit and he recommended this unit because it "worked good" and "it was reasonably priced".  As far as I'm concerned, the cost of the unit has a direct relation to the quality of the unit.  I will throw this unit away, cut my losses and move to another brand.  So long HP!

Title: Easy setup and good software.
Review: The software is clean and smart. I had no problem installing the software on multiple computers in my home and sharing this printer. It was a good deal and I have had no problems with it.

Title: UGH!!!!
Review: I am very disappointed in this printer --- if I had known that printing an envelope is all but immpossible ---- never ever would have purchased -- there is no way to load a single envelope w/o removing the paper tray --- removing the paper --- inserting the envelope --- adjusting the guides ---- adjusting the software to proper size envlope and then crossing your fingers that this sucker will work --- HORRIBLE design ----------- will sell this sucker for cheap!!

Title: Worst engineering.
Review: Within a week the printer broke. Its touch screen thinks that it is being touched and it tries to random things.One would have thought that the HP engineer would know how to interface a printer to a touch screen.

Title: Love love love this product
Review: This printer scans quickly and clearly, copies piles of documents without jamming, and is very easy to use.  Haven't used the fax function yet but the other functions work great and the user interface is easy to use.

Title: Serious connectivity issues make the printer usless
Review: I could not get the printer to connect wirelessly to my router due to a password issue. The printer still would not connect even after changing my router's password. I called HP support and they said the problem was with my router. I told them that my previous HP printer connected to my router with no problem and that my three laptops connect to the router with no problems. They insisted that the router is broken!!! SO I gave up on the wireless connection and connected the printer to the router via a cable. The printer connects to the network until it goes into hibernation, then it loses its internet connection to the router and will not wake up unless I unplug the network cable and plug it back in.This is a well known problem that HP refuses to address:[..]

Title: FAULTY PRODUCT
Review: PROS: The printer was easy to set up and did a great job. The picture quality was excellent. It printed fast. When it would turn on...CONS: Quit responding and working after only 2 MONTHS. I tried everything. The screen would not turn on. The computer said it was off. Called tech support and 50 minutes later they decided that it was faulty hardware. Sending me a new printer that I'll receive in a week. Made me give my credit card number in case I didn't send the old broke one back. Sending a REFURBISHED UNIT, Not a new unit. Effectively, the refurb will serve out the remining 266 days of my warranty (Their refurb policy is 90 day warranty or the rest of your term). RUN TO A DIFFERENT MORE RELIABLE BRAND!

Title: HP 8600 Family of printers
Review: I purchased an HP Officejet Pro 8600 Premium printer. The installation was easy. I experienced 3 significant problems with it:1. The color tone was disappointing. Reds looked brown. Technical assistance advised to install new ink cartridges in place of the set-up cartridges. The new cartridges definitely improved the color, but still not perfect. Can't understand why the ink in the set-up cartridges would be different.2. Whenever I printed a color image, about 3 to 4 one-half inch wide significantly dark bars would appear on across the image horizontally in normal print. In 'best' quality print, the bars would disappear. After spending 3 hours with the technical assistant we gave up. Technical assistant acknowledged a problem.3. I could not get the printer to feed 110 lb. card stock.I returned the above printer, & tried the HP Officejet Pro 8600 plus e-all-in-one N911g. This is essentially the same printer as above only with one tray. This printer printed about 4 to 5 faint black lines horizontally across the image about 3 points thick evenly spaced across the image in normal print. In 'best' quality print, the lines would disappear. I spent about an hour with technical assistant. Technical assistant sent to me a new print head assembly which seemed appropriate. The new print head made absolutely no change. This one too would not feed cardstock. I have returned this one as well.Simple black & white printing was just fine with both printers. All other features seemed to work.I'm using a brand new Dell laptop with Windows 7 Home Premium OS, & loaded HP's drivers from their CD.Based upon this experience I'm purchasing a different brand of printer.Seems like HP's quality has deteriorated dramatically.I have an 8 year old HP G85 all-in-one that still works very well, but it's incompatible with Windows 7 unfortunately, & HP does not have an updated driver for it.

Title: Not very good
Review: Bought this about 2 months ago and had nothing but trouble.  Constant jams, slow printing and poor coloration.  I've already bought another printer as this one is too much trouble.

Title: A few improvements would help this printer
Review: MEETING EXPECTATIONS:(1) I ordered this printer in December, 2011. It arrived promptly, set up easily, including wireless for PC users.(2) It had good life in the print cartridges printing a few pages/week use for each of four people(9 months). The setup cartridges made it through the summer, just two have needed to be replaced to date.(3) I'm very happy with the fax feature - it works well, can be set up to allow another answering machine to pick up, and will accept manual prompt to receive fax. It has caller ID onscreen, too.(4) Standby feature conserves electric wtihout making printer unavailable.  DISAPPOINTMENTS:(1) This printer cannot handle cardstock. I can understand two-sided printing might be difficult on cardstock, but for one-sided applications, this should be possible.(2) This printer is TOO smart. My old HP printer would crank away with a low or empty cartridge - the finished product would show it. Now, I want to print in black and white, but since my yellow ink cartridge is empty, NOTHING will print. HP, are you desperate to sell more ink?! Let us mess up our printouts if we want to! LOL! There is a black-cartridge only option to select - but it only works when the color cartridges are working.(3) The helpful color touch screen also looks for many ways to encourage you to print apps. It should be possible to preview pages on-screen without ALWAYS needing to print it, sight unseen (wasting both ink & paper).  LEARNING THE HARD WAY:(1) Contacting '24 hour HP support' means a self-guided help menu. DO NOT count on it addressing your particular issue (why does the printer say replace cartridge when it is full), or easily being able to get a question answered except through submitting 'in-warranty' claims.(2) I replaced the Black setup cartridge with the 950XL cartridge. Then the yellow cartridge ran out. Then (I haven't gotten a yellow cartridge yet)the printer told me the black cartridge must be replaced (after one week's use). TURNED THE PRINTER OFF AND THEN BACK ON. NOW it knows the black cartridge is full. (As in 'reboot it!')(3) When it says 'replace a cartridge soon' - as my yellow one - it means you might be able to print only ONE more page before the printer will not print ANYTHING (in any color or even using black cartridge only). I didn't want to stockpile ink and have it become 'old', but do need to have it in advance or live without printing until getting more.  SUMMARY:Over all a decent, capable printer, but HP, why not tweak it into a wonderful printer?!

Title: Not what's advertised
Review: If you are serious about scanning a lot of documents, and if you want to do so at a resolution higher than 300 dpi, this printer is not for you.  HP does not tell you in their data sheet, but the ADF will not scan higher than this resolution.  So unless you want to feed a pile of documents by hand, stay away from this and buy another brand such as Epson that keeps their word.  I haven't owned this device long enough to find out whether there are other hidden flaws, but given the way that HP seems to have decided to cheapen their machines (another example: removing the telephone FAX function from the 7510) I will not be surprised to find that there are more.

Title: HP improves, but can do better...
Review: I have had this model now for about 4 months.Previously, my printer was another HP, a K80, which worked well, but had high ink costs and the scanner was only mediocre, leaving a vertical line down the scan that could not be removed.The 8600 produces excellent scans, and the ink cost is much lower, perhaps half their previous models - each cartridge lasts longer, and is cheaper.  There is a 'low ink' warning, about 50 pages before the end, and then, when the end comes, it just stops printing - a very satisfactory solution to this issue, it seems to me.Copying is generally good, with reliable paper handling.Faxing: I have not had any of the difficulties reported by earlier reviewers (but then my use of the fax function is limited to only 2 or 3 times a month).2-sided printing is easy and reliable.Two irritations:It does not handle thicker, heavier (than 20#) paper well, or even at all - heavy weight photo paper from Costco will not work.Most disappointing: the simple task of printing an envelope is freighted with difficulties.  Instead of simply choosing the size of the envelope in Word, you have to go into the 8600 setup and change the size of the paper!  Incredibly stupid. I fail to understand why HP cannot correct this with a software update, but so far it has stubbornly refused to even recognize that this is an issue.All in all, a good, perhaps even very good, multi-function printer, but with a couple of surprising negatives.

Title: Impossible to connect to this thing
Review: I've wasted the last 2 hours trying to connect to this HP printer. Absolutely disgraceful that I can connect to everything else in this house wirelessly yet this printer defies wireless and cable attempts. Windows and HP, a no work combination.

Title: Fast delivery good product.
Review: This printer produces professional color for up to 50% lower cost per page than lasers,accelerates productivity with apps on the large touchscreen, has networking options & is a versatile e-all-in-one performer.You also can easily print from a mobile device with HP ePrint.

Title: Worked great out of the box
Review: Printing works great from our home computer, work laptops (mac and PC), iPad and IPhones.  I am a big fan of Air Print now.  Scanning, faxing, and copying all have been tried and seem fine too.  Setup was easy.  We've had 3 or 4 multifunction printers over the years and this is definitely the best.  I am writing this after owning the printer for about 4 months.

Title: Piece of crap Don't waste your money
Review: I always have issues with the printer catching paper other than standard weight paper. Not to mention it wont configure with my postage program and only wants to print 4x6 envelopes. Will not print 5x7 on 5x7 paper or envelopes. I love HP products but this one is trash and has been since day one i bought it. If i had the receipt still I would return it in a heart beat!!!!!!!!!!!!! And the ink cost is OUTRAGEOUS!

Title: The darn thing only lasted about 7 months of average use....scanner light went.
Review: I bought this HP All in One figuring it would last me a couple of years....well guess what?  That's right...not!  The send a fax still works but that's it..... It appears that the scanner went which keeps it from printing faxes, scanning and copying...it refuses to stay connected....etc...etc..I bought this 'machine' about 7-8 months ago.  probably still under warranty but don't have box or receipt.  Shouldn't have had to even think about having to keep them for all this machine was talked up to be.

Title: Beware of Wireless""
Review: I bought this about a year ago, and since then, every two weeks, the printer goes nuts and stops talking to the rest of the network. You go to print or scan, and the device (PC or iPad) tells you it can't find the printer. You check the printer, and it thinks it's online with a valid IP address, but the printer can't be found. So, I call HP for help, and here's what they told me. 'It's your network; reboot your network and all your devices.' Ok, but after the first 5 or 6 times, I finally explain to them that of the dozen or so devices on my network - a couple of desktops, a couple of laptops, some tablets, smartphones, a cell phone microcell, and other devices - the ONLY device that seems to have a problem staying connected to the network is the printer. And to shut down the network and reassign IP addresses to the machines just because the printer can't handle it is stupid.So, I talk to HP Tech Support some more. They tell me to call my ISP, who doesn't work with internal networks. Finally, the guy from HP tells me that the default settings for my router can't just be default, that the HP only works with Channel 6 or some crap like that. He said it was one of those things that is not in the manual, but should have been told to me during my first tech support call.But then, sure enough, two weeks later, the printer goes nuts and goes offline again. It won't connect back up. Finally, at that point, the woman at HP says I should just connect it via USB. She says the wireless card is weak and can't go very far, and she wants to know how far from my router it is. I explain it's about a foot away from the router. She says again I should put in the USB slot, and I ask her what her definition of 'wireless' is.Finally, several weeks ago, I got a guy from HP who told me quite honestly that their wireless cards suck and that they can't stay connected. He said this was a known and common problem and that HP recommends that their printers are connected via a wire. 'If your printer is only a foot away from the router, why don't you connect it up via a wire?' he asked. Because I only have four ports, and they are taken by my devices that ONLY work via a wire. 'Well, I have one and had the same problems you do, so I connected it via a wire. Find a device you don't use, and connect this one in that place, and you can have the printer work ALL THE TIME!' I asked him why they marketed the printer as 'wireless' when they have these wireless issues? He said because HP has the best printers in the world. I threatened to dump this printer and get an alternative made by another company, and he said 'Good luck, HP makes the best. You'll be back to HP.' Kind of a flippant answer, but there you go. Oh, and he made the hard sell on additional coverage of tech support since mine is almost up. I told him before I gave HP another dime, I'd go with a competitor.I've spent about 16 hours total on the phone with tech support trying to make the wireless work, and I've finally given up and just gone wired.Anyway, it's been a couple of weeks now, and the WIRED HP printer is working just fine. Does all it's supposed to do, but I did have to go out and buy an additional 5 port switch, some wire, and plug in one more device into my already overflowing chain of surge protectors. Thanks for the useless 'wireless' feature, HP!By the way, I found that Canon makes a competing product, the PIXMA MX432. If this one goes nuts and decides he doesn't want to play nice with the rest of the network - again - I'm buying that one. Yeah, HP, you heard that - I WON'T be back!

Title: well worth ti
Review: I went through many $100-$200 printers (EPSON, LEXMARK, CANON, Low end HP printer, Dell...etc), and they all have been pretty disappointment. Either its poor quality or breaks down too quick.  So far, I have been very happy with HP officejet pro 8600 plus.  The quality is great for photo and presentation.  Saves on ink and i can use my phone or tablet to print any documents.  It was easy to install and and fairly quick to print document.  For ~$200 printer, this was worth the investment.  This printer provides so many option as to home network setup and able to scan to any local network pc.  Perhaps, I'm one of the lucky customer who have purchase an item with no issues and meet all expectation.

Title: Great Printer/Scanner!
Review: Exactly what I ordered... but not what I needed! I needed a TWAIN compatible scanner, but this was not it. But I like the product so much that I am planning to keep it! I guess I will have to start going to the Bank to deposit now, as the new version of OS does not support TWAIN!Love the ease of use. The setup happened pretty much automatically! Great product!

Title: excellent purchase
Review: I simply love this printer. Does everything it says it does. Picture quality its high and printing from my iPad has been made easy

Title: Amazing features, low price, great support from HP
Review: OK, I'm taking off one star because the front panel touch screen failed after 3 months.  However, a call to HP's support was amazingly speedy and helpful.  Maybe I just got lucky, but my call was answered by a human being within 1 minute and within 10 minutes on the phone, we'd tried a few things and determined it was a hardware failure and I had a replacement on the way.  I'm  not thrilled about getting a refurbished unit as a replacement, but they will still honor the original warranty, so as long as I don't have any additional problems, I'll be happy.I use this printer for my home-based business, which means that my teenage kids also use it for their school projects.  It replaced a trusty Brother MFC 7840w that was an absolute workhorse.  The only reason I replaced my trusty Brother MFC laser printer was because I was getting tired of the 10 pm runs to Kinkos to get color copies made for their school projects.The wife LOVES the Airprint capability - we are a 100% Mac household, with 4 iPhones, 2 iPads, an iMac, and 3 MacBooks, but the wife never uses a 'real' computer anymore now that she can print everything she wants from the iPad or iPhone.There are a TON of features on this printer - some useful, some gimmicky.  One neat feature is the ability to print the Sunday comics automatically (and lots of other things if you want).  You go online and configure the automatic printing apps you want installed on the printer, then schedule them to print the content you want and the time you want it.  You can easily get carried away (which I am sure is what HP wants so they can sell more ink!) but my 12 year old loves waking up every Sunday morning to his favorite comics, all printed in color.I have not had any paper handling issues, but other than printing double-sided, I'm not really stressing this thing much.  The construction is cheap plastic for the most part, but the 'bronze-brown' color is more pleasing to me than the old 'putty' colors that HP used to use on their office machines.As far as connectivity, access from the network, and set of software tools, I have been THRILLED with this unit.  HP really got it right with respect to being easy to setup and use in a Mac environment.  I can scan from any computer on the network, and even scan directly from the unit itself and choose the computer destination for the scanned files, INCLUDING my Synology Diskstation NAS (where I archive all my important documents).Hopefully, I will not be plagued by hardware problems that other reviewers have complained about, but my experience with the HP tech support was very, very good.

Title: Don't buy this printer
Review: After seven weeks the touch panel froze up, and HP is replacing it with a 'reconditioned' product instead of new.  DON'T BUY THIS PRINTER.  The customer service experience was worse than terrible, tech support was incompetent until I got to a supervisor after repeatedly begging for one, and it took me 2 hours and 10 minutes to get to the end of the process.

Title: What a printer!
Review: Thanks HP and thanks Amazon.  Great price...timely shipping...arrived without a scratch.  Hook up took all of about 30 minutes from the time I started unpacking to fully set up.  Chose to go wireless and had zero problems..truly plug and play.  My local network includes both XP and Windows 7 home and windows 7 pro.  I have sense connected the printer to the desk top XP machine to avoid IP conflicts with my windows 7 pro.  Quiet, fast, prints both sides automatically.  Really glad I made the purchase!

Title: Works Nicely
Review: After doing my due diligence and criss-crossing the web looking for a replacement for my Canon MP500 that up and quit, I finally settled on the Officejet Pro 8600 Plus.  Here is my experience.1. Out of the box - easy to get out and put together.  Either read the papers or carefully go over the device (my preference) and pull off all the tape and remove any cardboard or foam spacers.  Plugged it in and powered it up.2. After hitting the power button (on the front - bonus) and opening the front access panel, waited a minute for it to settle down and leave the print head where I could stick in the ink cartridges.3. Next I went through the configuration on the printer LCD touch screen (I never read any printed documentation, not necessary).  While no iPhone, the touch screen is responsive enough to be quite usable...even while typing the WPA password (wireless set-up was painless) on the QUERTY on-screen keyboard.  I finished the configuration without issue.  It concludes by printing out a page on how to customize ePrint.4. Tried out iPrint/AirPrint from iPhone.  Worked great.  Even duplex!  It does pause briefly between front and back printing to let ink dry.5. Went online and customized ePrint.  Why not have a more friendly email address for my printer?  Sent a test email with a Word attachment.  Came out nicely.6. Installed the full HP print/scan suite on an iMac (did full suite install since this is the machine we will be scanning from..more on that later).  No issues.  Just told it to skip initial printer set-up since I had already completed it using the LCD.  Printed without issue.7. Installed the printer via auto-discovery on a Mac laptop.  Used Apple supplied drivers.  Printed without issue.8. Installed the printer on a Win 7 laptop.  Downloaded the drivers from HP.  Printed without issue.  (Do be careful to uncheck installing all the crapware on Windows. eg. Bing toolbar)9. Time for some Scanning.  Brought up HP Scan on the iMac.  Stuck some pages in the document feeder and told it to go.  Check.10. Copy using document feeder worked as expected too.It is hard to ding a product that does what it should.  Print and scan quality is good.  Things I have yet to try: Initiate scan from printer to computer, Scan from printer to Google, send a fax.My only complaint so far is the HP Scan software is limited.  Seems like there used to be a HP Scan Pro application... will look at 3rd party solutions too.Very pleased thus far.  Will update later.Update 8/30/2012:Still not a fan of the supplied HP Scan software on the Mac; however, am very happy that I was able to use the available Mac Automator Scan action to create a 'Scan to Evernote' button I could put on the dock.  The other good news is that it is well supported by many third party scanning apps for the Mac.  VueScan works well but has quirky interface.  ScanDrop is a new app with promise, still many bugs it seems.Surprised at how much I use the ePrint (send/forward email with attachment to email address HP provides) to print a Word Doc or PDF email attachment.Very pleased with printing and ink use thus far.Update 4/14/2013:Two things to report.  First, after about 2200 pages, the automatic document feeder (ADF) broke.  It jammed, my wife cleared the jam and then it would simply not feed.Good news is that customer service was excellent; picked up the phone almost immediately and after about 45 mins. on the phone (went thru their troubleshooting steps), they declared the ADF unit unusable and sent me a replacement printer via FedEx overnight.  While an inconvenience, I was pleased with how HP handled everything.Second, I finally sent a fax!  While feeling slightly nostalgic, the fax was sent (over a Vonage VoIP phone line) just fine.  I will likely never use it again....but it works!I'm very happy with the print quality and ink use.

Title: Save your money!
Review: AMAZON IS THE BEST BUY!  The store named Best Buy claims to have a 30 return policy. I bought an HP printer from the so-called Best Buy store and I soon ran out of ink.  I also had a terrible time with the HP printer.  The HP printer had very little ink, it took forever too get the printer to start, it made a lot of noise when compared to other Brand named printers, it took a long time to print let alone shut down and it printed a test page that used up a great amount of INK without me directing it to.  The HP printer also has very little INK that comes with the HP printer and when I purchased extra regular INK cartridges I ran out very soon. I found this out with HP printers; very little INK.  If you buy a regular HP ink cartridge you are buying what I call a sample HP INK cartridge since it runs out of ink quickly.  If you think about it the HP cartridges that show 2.5 times more INK are the same size as the regular cartridges.  You then have to ask, 'how much ink do they really put in the regular OVER priced HP INK cartridges'?  I considered myself cheated when I bought the regular sized cartridge.  My personal opinion is that the HP 2.5 times more INK cartridges run out after printing only about 50% more than the regular overpriced HP INK cartridges while you end up paying a lot more.The only good thing about my experience with the Best Buy store is that I was able to try out the HP INK supply and the printers' performance!  I could suggest doing the same but I won't.  I will state that I wasn't shy returning the HP printer to the Best Buy store because I was not afraid of this chain store and I was not satisfied with the performance of the HP Printer.  Best Buy says you have 30 days to return the HP Printer you should have 30 days but this is a misnomer!  I tried the HP printer I bought from the Best Buy store and I didn't like its performance.  The Best Buy store states that you can return it within 30 days for a full refund if you don't like its performance.  I took the Best Buy store for their word and I returned the HP printer to the Best Buy store after 25 days of use.  The Best Buy store would not take the return without me signing a statement stating that I would not return anything I buy until after a 90-day period from the time I returned the HP Printer.  I should have told them to F off and accept my return without signing their statement.  The Best Buy store also wants a photo ID from everyone when they return something.  If the item is being charged back to your credit card then you should not have too give them any ID!  This amounts too invasion of privacy (Big Brother).  AMAZON IS THE BEST BUY!  AMAZON DOES NOT ASK FOR A PHOTO ID!My opinion is that the Best Buy store is not the BEST BUY! I believe Amazon is the BEST BUY!MY OPINION IS THAT Amazon does have the BEST BUY.  Amazon is not like the so-called Best Buy store.  It is my opinion that Amazon ALWAYS gives you the BEST BUY.  I will stay committed to Amazon and quit buying from the so-called Best Buy store.  Amazon has fantastic delivery, great service, in most states no tax, in most cases free shipping, extended warranties are available and Amazon will take care of any problems immediately, unlike the so-called Best Buy store!

Title: Consistently the Best Electronic Product I've Owned
Review: I'm a tech person (software engineer). I also care deeply about usability, simplicity, stability. I have owned many printer/scanner thinggies over the years. But nobody has come close to HP's OfficeJet line. I owned a 7300 for 8 years. Fantastic workhorse. Did it all. Now I just bought the new 8600 - not so much because I really needed it (the 7300 was still kicking butt).This one goes a step further in putting all other multi-purpose printer things to shame. Excellent quality. Amazing speed. The cleanest, most brain-dead simple installation and setup across Windows, Mac OS, and iPhone/iPad. I can't find anything this machine doesn't do (except, maybe, that the envelop feeding is a little clumsier than it used to be - yet still perfectly usable).Oh - and did I mention that it's $207 on Amazon?! Everyone knows that HP gets you with the ink-jet cartridges. That's true and nothing that they tell you changes that. Cartridges are obscenely expensive. But taken all together, it's still an impossibly amazing device for the price.Alex

Title: Easy Wireless Set up
Review: I just bought my HP 8600 Plus all in one yesterday and set it up today for the first time.  I will likely update this review later, but given some reviews that talk about it being difficult to set up, I wanted to say how easy it was to set up wirelessly on my home network, which is DSL.  The printer set up on a home network is done directly from the printer display and all I had to do was follow the prompts.  I then set it up as instructed on our computers, with the CD provided. I was able to set up a work laptop with Windows XP, my personal laptop with Windows 7, and my son set up his desktop pc which I believe is also Windows XP.  The pc side set up was done easily and fairly quickly on all 3. I answered all questions when prompted and sailed right thru the set up.So far I have not got around to faxing.  The fax feature is something we will only use once in a while if needed, but it put an HP 8600 fax queue right on my work laptop (which I accidentally tried to use to print, and could not figure out why it was asking me for a fax number at first, lol.  You have to use the 8600 Network queue, duh).I bought mine at Staples on sale because I just didn't want to buy something so big off Amazon.  But don't buy the Staples protection plan if you purchase it there.  I did but will be going in to cancel that and get my money back because they actually described a different plan than the one they sold me.  I did buy my ink on Amazon today, much cheaper than Staples had, and a 4 pack of the XL cartridges also.____________________It has now been over 3 months, and I still love my printer.  Scanning is a breeze and so is copying.  I still have not got around to checking out all the other features available.  I don't print a lot of things, maybe not every day, but I print and copy whatever I want; sometimes for work at home days also.  I have almost gone thru 1 ream of paper at this point.  I've never had an issue with it at all, and I am still using the 'sample' ink cartridges that came with it, which Staples told me would only print 20 or so pages.  At this rate, the new set of ink I bought will be outdated before I get to use it!  I do like the copy feature choice of using black or color ink also._____________________1-1/2 years now and still no issues with this printer.  Faxing is a breeze with it also. just make sure you use a 2 line telephone cord.

Title: So far awesome printer
Review: configuring this printer on my windows 7 platform was beyond easy...HP really made things simple; HP has animations to setup the printer, trays and paper feed, all covered in the animations. Wireless setup from the dvd (printer driver install) was done with one click. I was surprise that HP acquire my network settings without asking me for my 128 character password. I printed a few pages, even created an email account with my printer to receive documents via email, awesome feature.  So far so good.

Title: Hp stands behind there product
Review: The wireless is nothing but problems for me but that may just be my network. The fax stopped working and HP sent out a replacement right away. Overall Im happy with it.

Title: A+ Printer, A+ Software
Review: There aren't many products I buy that I can truly say after several months of ownership that I'm ecstatic about but this is one.  I started looking at printers while walking through Walmart and noticed that you can get a printer for about the cost of replacement ink cartridges these days so I dove into printer reviews and settled on this one in spite of the much higher price.This printer delivers like a workhorse.  It is solidly built, the touch screen is awesome, the wireless capabilities are priceless, the separate ink cartridges are a great advantage, the paper tray holds much more paper than my last one did (250 sheets), it is FAST and crisp, and ALL controls are easy to understand.I have learned though that you can have a great printer and still want to throw it against the wall if the software isn't robust and easy to use.  The software shines in little ways that I never would have considered possible.  For instance there is a particular document that I make copies of fairly regularly.  I have set up a 'profile' for this document so that just by selecting this profile the printer remembers that it's a duplex project (and all the other settings) AND the directory to store it in!  I've never seen anything like it.  It makes electronic filing SOOOOOO easy!  I can scan directly into a multi-page PDF - I never could do that before.I have connected XP, Vista, and Win 7 machines to it wirelessly without any problems.  I have never used the ePrint features (can't imagine why I would ever want to) so I can't comment on it.  I've seen reviews of people complaining about the fax options but I've had no problems.  I've faxed long documents flawlessly and received faxes that are clear.  It took me a while to find it but I was able to turn off the fax speaker through the settings (and I really appreciate this feature).One minor issue and one wish - the issue is that on one occasion I had a paper jamb and had absolutely no way to salvage the jammed paper that was coiled onto the roller except to cut it out with a razor.  A little more help with stuck paper would be helpful.  The wish is that there could be a paper level monitor similar to the ink level monitor, but I get that you have to draw the line somewhere!If you are like me and you consider it worth it to spend a little extra for features and functionality that make a HUGE difference in the user experience then I can't recommend this printer any higher.  The only thing that could make me happier would be to add to this review that it is still performing like this after ten years!============================================================2013-Jan .....  Fatal Printer Error after 9 months of use============================================================The printer stopped working.  Was getting paper jamb errors when there was no paper to be found, followed up by 'printer failure' message related to the ink system ( I had just replaced the first print cartridge since I've owned the printer).  To HP's credit their customer service dept was available very late night and walked me through several tests, then when they determined that the printer was no longer salvageable they told me they would send me a new one (although it's going to be a refurbished one; not sure how much I like that but I'll give them the benefit of the doubt for now).  Incidentally it was virtually impossible to find a phone number on their site for customer support.  Like all companies now days they try every way they possibly can to make you resolve your issue without an actual conversation with a person, but I called their sales number and they patched me over to customer support ;)I plan to write an update after this gets resolved but I'm giving them credit for sending a replacement and an easy way for me to return the existing printer.  Oh, and they are also sending new ink cartridges - nice touch!  For now I'll leave this as a 5-Star review because other than this I really like this printer.  Subject to revision of course...

Title: May or May NOT be Wireless
Review: I have used this printer for 3 months and all of a sudden the wireless capability stopped working.  The printer shows all the correct settings and says it is connected but shows up offline on the computer.  Have reset everything possible multiple times and printer will not connect wirelessly.  Have uninstalled HP software and re-installed.  Even reset the whole home network.  Other wireless notebooks and other wireless printer all work fine - only this printer will not work.  In searching for solutions on internet I have found numerous complaints about this same issue since December 2011 - at least 8 months now and still no fix from HP for this issue.  When the printer works, the color docs are beautiful but I have had more problems with this printer in just 3 months than all the other printers I've owned for about 20 years put together.The other issue I had with this printer is that 1/2' to 3/4' space is added to all my document margins on the left side of every page and doc is cut off on right side of page.  There is no fix for this problem either - seems to be a printer diver issue.HP Support has no fix for either of these issues and does not seem to be in any hurry to find a solution.  Avoid purchasing this printer until there is a new driver.  Otherwise the wireless feature may fail at any time and document margins change on their own without regard to your software program settings.  If HP could correct those issues, this would be an excellent printer.  Without a driver update, this printer is totally worthless.

Title: Far from reaching expectations!
Review: I purchased this all-in-one printer to replace my 6-year old Canon printer when the print head went bad.  I had owned an HP printer prior to the Canon, and at the time swore that I would never purchase one again, but I didn't follow my instincts and chose this printer for its wireless capabilities, fast printing, high dpi scanning, memory stick ports and positive user reviews.  4 months in, I'm ready to dump it!Pros:  Wireless was really easy to setup, along with mobile printing.  Works great.  I love the ability to scan directly to any pc connected to the printer. Printing is fast once it starts, but it can sometimes take up to 90 seconds to receive the print signal.  Adjustable scan quality gives greater control when scanning photos.Now the cons:Scanning photos is a pain!  I used to be able to lay 4 to 6 photos out on the scan bed of my Canon (and my old HP for that matter!) and it would scan, separate and crop them automatically.  This one does not.  It will only give you the full scan and leave all the time-consuming editing to you.  I tried feeding the pictures through the ADF, but it only cut off part of the picture and left a permanent line down the face of the photo from the feeder.  Plus, the scan interface (pc) is not very user friendly and does not make it easy to scan several pictures in a row.  It's easier to do that from the scanner control pad, but you cannot access the dpi settings from there.  VERY frustrating!The ADF doesn't work very well.  If you need to feed more than a few pages at a time, plan on doing it in small batches.  It does not 'catch' the papers well and requires force-feeding to start.  More than a few pages and it will grab 2-3 at a time and jam up.  I've tried cleaning the roller but that didn't help.Another issue I have had is that I use Remote Desktop Connection for work, and I cannot print to this printer unless it is connected directly to my pc by usb.  Customer support is minimal.  From what I could see on the support forums, there are many others who experience this issue with no way to resolve it.  When I contacted them by phone, I was told that there was no solution due to the lack of driver support.  I had to purchase a separate cheap printer just for work, making this printer even more expensive!The memory card slots are basically useless.  They are designed only to print from, but I cannot transfer the files on the card to my pc.Although it does have duplex printing, it only has one paper tray to feed from.  This makes it difficult for specialty paper like checks and forms and re-using paper.I often experience lock-ups with this printer, where I have to unplug it for a few minutes to get it back up.My issues may not be important to most users of this printer - if you want something that will just print wirelessly, this is a great printer for that, but priced much higher than most average printers that will do that job well.  I paid the extra for this printer because of its special features and was very disappointed.

Title: happy customer
Review: the pro 8600 was easy to set up & easy to use, found it was faster than my canon 4600. good quality print

Title: No wireless while connected to VPN
Review: I purchased the HP Officejet Pro just a few weeks ago after moving to a home office and was very disappointed to learn that I am unable to use the wireless feature while connected to a VPN. What's the point of wireless if you can't use it? That was a real let down. The work around is to use a USB cable. Wish I would known this in advance.

Title: Don't bother.
Review: Before purchasing this printer I did not look at any reviews.  My mistake.  If you are smarter than I and you are already reading this: DO NOT PURCHASE THIS PRINTER.The printer does not feed photo paper.  I am using the expensive, 5 of 5 star HP Premium Plus paper.  Does not work.  I will not be bothering with little tweaks like rubbing my shirt on the roller wheels to make them less slick or taping paper to get it to print, rather: I will simply be returning it.  The printer fails to perform one of it's primary functions of printing photos.If you don't care about printing photos at all (in which case why did you buy an inkjet printer?) the printer works great.  Wireless setup was very easy.  Prints from iPad using the HP ePrint app.  I have always liked HP products and never considered buying anything else.  I had always used them myself and recommended them to customers when I worked at Staples and Best Buy.  That just changed.  Just bought the printer tonight and I will be returning it to Staples in the morning.

Title: Disappointed
Review: I got this all-in-one for my home office to replace an old HP inkjet. From the second I started unpacking it, I was frustrated. It was very heavy. There were so many pieces of tape hidden throughout the device. The trays felt light cheap plastic. You have to attach the duplex printer cartridge, which sticks out quite far in the back of the machine. You also have to make room for the output tray, which also takes a lot of room. The large size dwarfed my office and felt like a large black box was crowding the room. Wireless setup was difficult and it should have been a snap. I ended up needing a USB cable to set up my 'wireless' service. How dumb. Of course, it didn't come with the USB cable, so I had to go and spend more money. The interface was lovely, but seemed to take awhile to boot up each time. It also took too many keystrokes to perform some basic tasks. Once it was up and running, I expected to be home free... Immediately the printer hung and I had to reboot. Then paper jam errors appeared when there was no jam. Then the duplex printing didn't work. Troubleshooting software was no help. The ability to print via email was cool, though. As was the fact that all 4 print cartridges were not 'starter' versions. I didn't need or want to pay for the fax feature. So, I returned it for a much smaller Epson printer for half the price.

Title: Perfect for all of your stuff, basically!
Review: I got this fairly cheap with a trade-in offer at Office-depot, so cheaper than here on Amazon but am SUPER pleased with it!  You can put it anywhere because its wireless...we have two computers connected to it and they are both in different rooms.  You can scan and have whatever document/photo you have scanned saved as a variety of formats, PDF, JPEG, etc.  I have plans to scan all of my old pictures and save them on a HD so I can print them and enlarge them later, PERFECT!  It also prints double-sided so you use less paper!  I have to print a TON for grad school projects so I'm pleased that I can save on paper use!  And it makes it cheaper.The ink is a bit expensive but aren't all ink cartridges, basically?  I had one day when the wireless connection for some reason didn't work real well but after speaking on the phone with a nice trouble-shooter my problem was fixed w/in 30 minutes and I didn't have to pay for that service because it was included in the Warranty.Thank you HP for making a product that I could have used YEARS ago!

Title: Works fine now that I figured out the install
Review: Great printer. Works great with XP. The software is a little clunky compared to the HP 1536dnf I recently used. Which is a shame because the 8600 is a much better piece of hardware. There is no seperate icon for scanning or faxing with the 8600 as there is in the 1536. You have to load the 'main' menu which seems to recompile itself everytime you use it. I found the scan icon in the program files and copied it to the desktop so that I don't have to go through so many steps to scan. I have not been able to fax using the print function (I tried it out) and have not bothered yet because I have a fax modem in the computer with seperate software for faxing. Faxes fine when faxing directly from the 8600.The printer was very sensitive to the power strip. I had to adjust the prongs to make it work. An HP laser printer at work burned out because it does not like a power strip and wants to be plugged into the wall. My usage is much less so for me I doubt the power stip will be an issue.Don't bother to install the software using the disk from HP on windows 7 or 8. Download the software from the internet and you will be fine.

Title: HP Officejet Pro 8600 Plus is not 600 lines/inch scanner
Review: Field test of the HP Officejet Pro 8600 Plus shows that the practical resolution is only 350 to 450 lpi, not the claimed 600 dpi.  The pixel granularity appears to be 600 dpi, but linear resolution in .jpg cases is limited to the lower numbers due to what appears to be occluding by jpeg compression.  Tif scan shows 600 dpi pixel granularity at 400 to 600 lines/inch pattern, but moire patterns interfere with resolution at 500 lpi.But the scanner resolution is visibly better on this tested model than the lower-priced 8600.-- Roy ZiderRated: 600 dpiMeasured: about 400 lpiScanned: 7/21/2012 11:24 at Best Buy, Oakland, CAScan target: A&P PM-189 (15 lines in funnel patterns)Jpg compression generally clouds the linear resolution above 300 lines/inch.Page orientation on flatbed is different than other manufacturers.  HP wants the head/top of doc on the right, not on the left.

Title: Ink
Review: The printer is excellent, the issues I have is that, it said I needed a new ink cartridge even though it was doing a great job of printing.It wouldnt let me print until I had to put in a new cartridge, even though there was no need.It could be because I was printing one line on 3x5 cards.  But even still, I should decide when the print quality is unacceptable, not HP!

Title: great printer!
Review: Simply a great printer for small business or home offices.  Easy to use, multi functional, and meets all your needs.

Title: Best All-In-One Printer I've Found
Review: I have had the previous model (8500 Pro) and the the Epson 837 all-in-one. This review will be in comparison to those models.
