Despite the Epson receiving great reviews, I find that the HP's are consistently better. Both HP's have been really solid overall, and particularly when it comes to the functions that really matter in an all-in-one. That is, scanning, copying (flatbed or feed-style, and dual sided), network reliability and ease-of-use, and of course printing quality and speed. The HP is excellent in each of these categories, and also has a much more intuitive interface than the Epson. Conversely, the Epson has been very annoying to use. Trying to setup any network features beyond the most basic has been a real pain. Additionally, it prints too slowly and the feed-mechanism just plain sucks. They decided to go with form over function. You really need a printer that is a little larger in order to gain some necessary functionality. The HP 8600 is the perfect blend of form and function in my opinion.Now, I got the new 8600 model only because I wanted to be able to print from my iPad. To my surprise, this printer also provided a significant improvement above my already-great 8500 in almost every way. The printer works so well, and all of the network functions have been so easy to set up, that I am almost in disbelief. Every aspect of my previous printer that I thought was great before, has been improved in this model. The double-sided copying and printing is a lot better and faster than it was before. On top of each of the categories I mentioned in the paragraph above, this printer also has a better screen, more network functionality, and the printer is a bit sleeker as well.One last thing I'd like to mention is that this printer has a great feature that I have been hard pressed to find in any other printer on the market--the ability to forward incoming faxes to your email or computer. I haven't started using this feature yet, but I've always been annoyed that I couldn't do this in the past. I think the benefits of having all your incoming faxes automatically converted to a digital format and sent to your inbox are pretty clear. Good job HP.

Title: Another excellent HP Inket printer
Review: The next in the evolution of the HP Inkjet multifunction printers. I love it. Quick printing, low ink use. Wonderful!

Title: HP Officejet Pro 8600 Plus
Review: Love this printer/copier/fax machine! Haven't tried making photograph copies yet, but it is an easy machine to set up & operate. Copies are crisp and clear, response time is quick and fax set up a breeze. Highly recommend this item. Fast delivery - great Amazon service as usual.

Title: June/John
Review: We purchased the HP Officejet Pro 8600 Plus printer to replace a Lexmark printer.  The quality of the printer when printing documents is great.  The issue is that it will not print envelopes in MS Word 2007.  HP lists this as a 'known problem' and offers a solution that did not work.  Amazon should list all of the 'known problem' so that you can make an educated decision about if you want to buy this product.  We are very dissatisfied with this purchase!

Title: Very difficult to configure and use
Review: I really, really wanted to like this printer. I did a ton of research on Amazon comparing it to many other all-in-ones before buying this one. I'm a pretty tech savvy person and generally able to handle all my home IT needs. However, this printer has never worked well since I purchased it just over 30 days ago. My computer often cannot find either the printer or scanner on the network whether I am connected by wire or wireless. It has been overall an extremely frustrating experience that has wasted so much of my time. I'm so frustrated that I just logged on to Amazon to figure out how to return this thing, but unfortunately it doesn't look returnable. So I am resorting to writing a rare review (for me) on Amazon.I advise anyone not to buy this printer. I can't imagine other printers would be harder to configure. I have actually installed and re-installed the printer drivers / setup / configuration multiple times. I should give it one star instead of two, but as I said I really want to like this printer.

Title: Great product--poor set up instructions
Review: Amazon did their part and the All-in-One arrived in excellent shape.  Setting it up on a wireless system was another matter with the D-Link wireless router.  It took a technical rep using a special program to allow him to operate my computer and lap top over a two day period to get the thing to function properly.  Fortunately for me the tech support person hung in there until we got almost everything working.  He had to use our lap top which was set up wireless in order to get my computer and new HP unit to function wirelessly.  The computer had not been hooked up wireless before I got this new printer as the old HP All-in-One was not capable of wireless operation.  I later found out that the new unit would not fax wirelessly and I had to hook up a phone line to the unit to get it to fax.  It all works now.  It is nice to be able to print from my wife's lap top using the wireless capability of this unit.Phil

Title: HP Officejet Pro 8600 Plus e Wireless All-in-One
Review: Ordered through Amazon and arrived timely and intact. Have been using this device for a couple of days now and absolutely LOVE it! The device led me through the entire set-up process. We needed fax capability and have only one VOIP phone line. Set-up for this was also led by the device and CD, which was included, and print, copy, fax, scan and my voice mail are all working together very well. Wireless connection was also a breeze. And, HP has an easy-to-use set up that allows you to print from your smartphone to the printer. I have already recommended this product to 2 other people.

Title: Works great, BUT (you knew there was a 'But')
Review: Totally a great printer. Like all HP printers it does sound like it's giving birth when it prints, but I expected that.BUT, don't drink the KoolAid about the ink use. It uses ink as fast as any other printer.

Title: The worst printer for my small business ever!!!
Review: I have owned this printer for less than a year and here is what I experienced.1. It's makes a lot of noise, even when it hasn't started printing.2. It's constantly doing some sort of system check, or maintenance--so if  you want to print something tomorrow, you better start the print today!3. It's constantly reporting incorrect ink levels--I can't even remember how many new ink cartridges I threw away because the machine said they were empty--I've put brand new ones in there and they report them as 'ink getting low'4. It wastes lots of ink.5. It will quit printing in the middle of a job, and is very spotty on printing the jobs it has. It takes so long to start printing that you think the job didn't go through, so you print again--then its not unusual to get multiple copies the following day.6. The sheet feeder is already broken. I actually have to buy another printer now--FYI...I have almost $200 worth of ink for this printer, and it's unlikely I can return it--I ordered it online a few months ago.7. The printer is bulky, and heavy--yet has surprisingly cheap plastic parts--like the paper tray cover that falls off all the time.I actually started disliking this printer almost immediately. I would have returned it, but I bought it online, and it would have cost a fortune to return it. There's more complaints, but I'm tired of wasting anymore time on it.BE WARNED!HP, if you're reading this, you can replace my printer, and a little goodwill can go a long way with me.

Title: Excellent Printer
Review: The printer arrived earlier than promised by Amazon.  I have used this printer in my home for a month, linked to a PC running Windows 7, and am completely satisfied.  I mostly print short documents, but also copy and scan.  I no longer fax, so I cannot comment about that.  Wireless set up is straight forward, easy and went smoothly, using their wizard.  Quality of printing is excellent, and colors appear true.  I bought this printer to replace a broken HP Office Jet 6500.  It is much faster, quieter, and prints higher quality documents.  Printing on two sides of the paper is fun, works well, and saves money.  So far ink usage appears to be reasonable.  I like the touch screen for inputing instructions, and prompts seem easy to understand.  Of all the printers that I have owned over the years, this one (so far) seems to be the best.  I hope that it is reliable.

Title: Not as good as I hoped
Review: Purchased this printer in December 2011 for my office (I'm a solo attorney). I wanted one that could scan, copy, and print and fit into my budget. Generally, the printer has been working fine, but there are two main problems that still annoy me.1. The built-in HP scanning software results in very large pdf files. I often need to scan documents that are 25+ pages, and when I do that just by pushing the buttons on the front of the printer or by using the scan utility that comes with the printer, the scans are often way too big to email or upload. After much searching on the web, the only solution I've found is a workaround--I downloaded a free pdf utility (PDFill is the one I use) and use that program's 'scan to pdf' functionality. This results in manageable pdf file sizes. This may not be a big deal if you're only going to scan one or two pages. I have read that this is a common problem with HP scanning software, so I will not be buying HP for my next multi-function printer.2. About 30% of the time when I try to print regular #10 envelopes from Word, the printer says 'paper mismatch' and won't print. Other times the envelopes print fine. I can't see that I'm doing anything different between the times it works and the times it doesn't. Shutting the printer off and on again doesn't fix it when it decides there is a paper mismatch, nor does taking the envelopes out of the tray and replacing them a thousand times. This is really annoying when it happens, but it doesn't happen all the time. Fortunately, most of what I do is by email, so I don't often have to print envelopes.Otherwise, the printer is fine. I've printed or copied about 2500 pages since I bought it and the quality and speed are both acceptable. I've printed color photos on regular paper and they look very good. I've scanned color photos and they turn out fine for my purposes (attaching them to a report or something). The price was certainly better than other options. But I can't recommend it due to the two issues mentioned above.

Title: Great printer
Review: We have owned our 8600 for about 6 months now and we love it. It is much faster at printing than our old HP printer and the print quality is fantastic.

Title: Great machine
Review: I have had this printer for a little less than a month now and am very happy with how well it's working!  It was very easy to get connected to our wireless network and up and running.  It scans perfectly and spits out copies quicker than any other copier/fax we have had for our office.  I would highly recommend this to anyone looking for a copier that does it all.  But then again, I have only had it for one month.. we'll have to wait and see how it lasts over time.

Title: HP Officejet Pro 8600 Plus
Review: Works well out of the box.  Takes a little tinkering to set up the eprint-use the instructions in the instruction manual.  For networking-make sure you have your IP address and network password available.  You may get a message to attach a USB to finishing setting up the network; but I didn't have to do this-it was already set up, but I still kept getting the messsage.  Prints reliably and fast.  Don't forget to go to the HP website to download the new updates especially the one to correct a 'scan-can't find' glitch in the event you want to scan without any problems.

Title: Great Printer & Price
Review: The HP 8600 Plus is simply  a fantastic printer.  The seller is great as well, the orginal delivery date was a good week longer than the actual delivery date.  I had no problem installing it (but I had a home network in my home already and am running windows 7) I had to simply go by the short written instructions and less than 10 minutes later the printer was up and working just fine.  Have any problems HP is pretty good about assisting their customers.I am considering purchasing a second printer and I will be going back to the same seller once again....A+++ seller!

Title: Fantastic printer, love it!
Review: First I want to write a little comparison review. I recently purchased an Epson 845 WorkForce, based on price and many glowing reviews. What a mistake! The Epson Touchpanel was HORRIBLE! On the Epson, the touchpanel was like looking at a blur, which is totally useless if you want to print pictures, not to mention, Epson's touchpanel looks like an embarrassingly amateurish design, as if it was designed with 1990's technology, UGLY and unintuitive, you literally had to look at a key to find other settings, also the Epson was slow to copy and print. I sent that crappy printer back to Staples. It always amazes me that people will give excellent reviews to a horrendous product just because they saved a few dollars, which is the case for the Epson 845.I now purchased the HP OfficeJet Pro 8600 Plus, and I'm in awe of it's touchpanel. So incredibly intuitive, easily navigated, offers a whole host of features that are intuitively presented. Plus, HP's touch panel is crystal clear, so when you need to print one picture from many of the same shot, you can easily distinguish which one of the pictures is the better of the group.The HP 8600 print speed is blazing fast, also incredibly fast copy speeds via the automatic document feeder. Print quality is absolutely gorgeous! Software setup was simple and fast. I did download the software from their web site rather than install from the CD.Oh, and this printer is unbelievably QUIET. Seriously, the quietest inkjet I've ever experienced. I've owned a few inkjets in my time, and some of them sound like Geppetto's workshop on a busy day. I was stunned when I printed my first page, and the noise was so low, especially compared to other inkjets I've owned.The HP OfficeJet Pro 8600 Plus, also offers an incredible amount of features via wired and wireless networking. I have my printer connected via ethernet, and I can access its settings page via IP address, and it's astonishing the amount of information and settings offered.One problem I've experienced so far, though it may have been improper settings on my part. The 8600 was having problems grabbing heavy stock paper. I had HP's Advanced Photo paper in the printer, and it wouldn't grab the paper to feed it through. I searched around for a solution, and others have complained about this as well. Some say it's a hardware issue, others claim software, others say to ensure you choose a tray output upon submitting a print job. For me, the fix for the problem seemed to be choosing a paper tray. I noticed a second paper tray was listed in my print settings, so before I sent the print job, I ensured Paper Tray 1 was selected. After that, it grabbed the HP Paper with no problems.One other complaint, though this seems to be the trend amongst all inkjet manufactures. NO MANUAL FEED! Why remove one of the best, time saving, and most convenient feature? Why?! I've always used a manual feed for when I just need to print one job on photo paper, or just print a couple of labels, or print one envelope. PLEASE! BRING BACK A MANUAL FEED!!!!!Overall, compared to its competitors, the HP is a little more expensive, but the quality of engineering and design is leaps and bounds ahead of the rest.

Title: excellent printer, scanner, copier
Review: The printer, scanner and copier work very well - easy to use, good quality print, doesn't use too much ink.  I haven't been able to figure out how to use the fax, however.

Title: Hp 8600 Printer
Review: I read a lot of reviews and I must say that this HP Officejet Pro 8600 Plus printer is all I had hoped. I love being able to print from anywhere in my house from any of my computers. It is fast with good quality printing. It was easy to install and very easy to use.

Title: Disappointed - If you want a good auto scanner do not buy
Review: I upgraded from a HP 6500w to this scanner because I wanted duplex scanning.  Scans through the ADF are almost always crooked, not just a little crooked either, really crooked.  I tested the model in the store before buying and noticed that scans were crooked there but was hoping it was just because the floor model had been used and abused.  This was not the case.  Other than the crooked scanning the printer seems to work well.  One star from a guy who does more scanning than printing.I took it back to the store.  Will stick with my 6500w for now.

Title: Excellent machine!
Review: I felt compelled to write this review given the outstanding performance of this printer.Since we plug it in we have been printing several reams of paper per day. The printer is fast, quality is good, and it hasn't had any problems so far. The cost of ink is reasonable.All in all a great machine for volume printing.

Title: Fantastic machine!
Review: Received in no time!  Love this printer/scanner et whatever else it does!I was hoping to use this printer with new PC and Apple IMac.... Since I use the IMac more I send my scans to it, it works so fast and it saves me some serious time.Prints fast, fax fast... That said, I'm getting rid of all the other printers in my office.  This is the bomb!  I'm glad I spent the extra dollars!  Worth it!

Title: Terrible printer
Review: The color printing does not work on this brand new machine even after buying new cartridges and spending a hour of wasted time with HP support.  The paper feed works poorly, and it becomes annoying being told that it would work better with HP paper. (This shows up on the screen.)There are more problems...it is being sent back tomorrow.

Title: Best printer we've owned
Review: Purchased at Costco while on special several months ago.  Has turned out to be the absolute best printer we've owned.  The dual side printing is an especially nice function.  Have no trouble with either the fax function or the software.

Title: Great for home office and school
Review: Very pleased with this printer!  It arrived as advertised and was easy to set up.  We have 3 computers that share this printer via our wireless network. I work from home sometimes and needed to be able to print documents letter and legal and work off the web.  My daughter is in college and has been able to utilize the scan features effectively for assignments.  The color is great for printing what we do and reports etc.  Very happy with this purchase!

Title: Great printer for the money
Review: Just purchased this printer as a replacement for an older printer, as we needed higher quality pictures and this printer sure delivers.Setting up the WiFi was a breeze and the quality, speed and ease of operation are all excellent for the price.  It comes with low capacity cartridges to get you up and going, but even these seem to be lasting well, so the full capacity versions (which we bought as well) should give long usage, and their price is reasonable.Although we've only just bought this model, so far, we are delighted and would recommend it.

Title: HP Officejet Pro 8600 Plus
Review: This unit was a replacement for an older HP printer and a fax to consolidate as one piece. I hooked it up per instructions. All of the features worked without problems. I've had it a month and it just works.

Title: Does Not Play Nice With XP
Review: The printer driver crashes every 4 hours on xp machines. This is a know bug and HP has not corrected it.

Title: I'm Happily Surprised
Review: I bought an 8600 Plus about a month ago after a lot of research, to replace an office Canon MP830 that had given great service as a printer/copier/scanner/fax. I'm very pleased with the 8600 Plus so far. I'll mention just a few things:I've been impressed by the usefulness of the touch-screen. It's definitely a new-generation user interface, compared with the Canon. The HP also uses sound tones to indicate certain events/functions; the Canon had nothing comparable.The WiFi capability made it easy to connect the 8600 with office computers via my wireless router, with setup through the touch screen. (I've had to re-set IP addresses a couple of times, but that hasn't been a major difficulty.)This HP is FAST, and does a great job printing quality text and graphics - no drop in quality from the Canon. I've also printed one photo (on photo paper); it printed quickly and looks great - no bands or unevenness, and excellent color.My biggest surprise is discovering this printer is an ink miser. I'd been wary of HP printers, due to their ink-hog reputation a few years back. The 8600 is using much LESS ink than the Canon it replaced. My ink costs will drop considerably if this continues - I'm still on the first set of tanks, after a lot of printing.I've scanned several documents to PDF, and have found the process easier than with the Canon MP830.My one disappointment is that, as purchased, the 8600 Plus loads paper only through a cassette. The Canon MP830 offered both open-feed (from the back) and cassette options, allowing me to choose two paper types from the software interface. That's a minor irritant, but I mention it because I assumed the 8600 would have an open-feed capability.SIX-MONTH UPDATE: The printer is still running well. I finally replaced the first set of ink tanks over the past month or so, and installed double-quantity tanks ('XL' in product numbers) to last even longer. Print quality is excellent - no banding or running at all. No jamming. I've done a lot of double-sided printing with no errors. The IP-address update issue I noted above is still with me - every couple of weeks I need to update the printer's IP address in order for it to print. I think that's an issue with my wireless router, however. In all, I'm very pleased.

Title: All-in-one that does it all.
Review: UPDATE: the USB port on the front of the printer is powered even when the printer is in standby/sleep mode; nice for charging charging other devices.This printer really does it all.  One of the best features that I didn't realize the scanner had was the ability to scan directly to a network share so you don't even need to have your computer on if you have a NAS.The scanner supports FULL duplex scanning, it automatically flips the pages to scan both sides as well as flipping it back so that the pages don't end up upside down after being scanned.Nice touchscreen display to setup the printer and change settings etc.  The touchscreen could be more accurate but it gets the job done.The printer is a bit on the slow side but considering the price it does well, just don't expect it to be fast.As long as it holds up over time I think that it's a great printer with a big plus on the scanning side doing automatic double sided scanning to a network share, great feature!

Title: Neither the best nor the worst
Review: This arrived with a huge book, but that was deceptive - only 20 pages were in English, the rest were recaps in other languages. Although it claimed to be a Getting Started Guide, it left out information I would have found useful, like how to set the clock on the screen. Also, although this printer can be used with a USB cable or wireless, it doesn't include a USB cable. Luckily, I had an extra one around. For the price, you'd think they could spare a cable which the box itself calls 'essential'! Set-up was relatively easy, with a few quirks. For example, the identification of outlets on the back of the printer are simply bas-relief black on black. Anyone who doesn't have excellent lighting and even better eyesight might be confused - as I was, since this printer is for home use and I didn't have a spotlight to aim at it. I'm a little dismayed at how large it is, but more important, I think the feeder tray on the top should have been detachable. Anyone (even a curious cat) can break it - it bent alarmingly when I just touched it. I haven't owned this long enough to see whether other problems arise such as were described in other reviews, but I'm worried about the possibility that it won't print only black if any color cartridge is out of ink, as several people have mentioned. Even on sale, this ink is incredibly expensive. This printer was very well regarded on the Consumer Reports website, which is why I purchased it for home use. My sister also purchased it, for business use, and I'm interested in seeing how it holds up for both purposes.

Title: Not bad...not great
Review: On the plus side, it's fairly fast and for an inkjet reasonably quiet.  The setup was fair - be careful when you first insert the ink cartridges. If you put the cartridges in wrong they'll jam and they'll jam in a part of the printer where you can't readily reach them to fix it.My biggest gripe is that envelope printing - which I do a fair bit of - is a major pain in the butt. Unlike my last OfficeJet where you just put the envelope in on top of the paper at the right place and alignment, here you have to REMOVE all of the paper, put the envelope in and adjust the guides. Then it feeds the envelope through BLANK on the first pass...so I guess I need to stick a second envelope or a sheet of paper on top.All in all, my OfficeJet 6500 seemed better for paper handling, but I do like the speed and features of the 8600Plus.

Title: Printer Freezes Up, Wireless Unreliable
Review: From the beginning I have been unable to reliably print any more than one page using the wireless connection. The printer loses connectivity and then prints many pages of black lines if I don't cancel the print job on the printer itself. I've ruined many pages of labels that way, until finally giving up and using a USB cord. Also the printer goes into a frozen state where the power and wireless lights blink and I can't even turn it off.

Title: Awesome Printer
Review: Normally, I do not participate in product reviews, but thought this unit deserved a 'thumbs up'.  I ordered this unit to replace a Dell printer that I had just returned for poor performance.  I have a small home office and this unit is perfect in all aspects for us.  It is very easy to set up including the 'wireless' which the Dell was not (could never get it to work at all).  The only thing I can see to improve performance would be to improve 'keypad' - you must press very hard at times.  All in all, a very good printer.

Title: Even Better Than I Expected!
Review: I have used many all-in-one printers and HP products, and this is by far the best! I love the wireless feature, and the scanner, copier and fax all work flawlessly. I purchased this for a home office, and it meets every need. It was completely easy to set up, and it is so user-friendly, I sometimes have a hard time believing it! It's rare that I can write a product review where there's absolutely nothing I don't like and the product is so much better than expected, but this is it!

Title: Excellent printer
Review: We had an officejet 7410xi that we bought at Costco about 7 years ago.  It was meant to be used when we needed to print either color documents or pictures, scan and fax feature.  Everyday document printing were done on our old HP 4 laser printer.  When that HP 4 finally died on us a few years back, the officejet 7410xi became the all purpose workhorse printer for us.  We loved it because of all the features and that it was a wireless printer.  Starting about 3 or 4 months ago, that printer started acting up where it would not print or the computer cannot find it on the network or it would stop printing in the middle of a print.  If these problems occur on only one computer then I might incline to believe that there was an issue with that one machine.  The similar problem cropped up on several machines.  I went so far as to connect it via USB to my gaming rig and the problem persisted.  Often, the only way to remedy it was to uninstall the printer driver and reinstall it again.  My wife finally got so fed up of having me resolve the printer issue for her that she insisted I looked into buying a replacement.Not sure how other people shops for electronic, I normally take several weeks of researching and reading up on people comments and publications review on several similar items, weighed the pros and cons, narrow down the list of possible choices, go back and read some more before I finally make a purchase.  That brings me to the HP Officejet Pro 8600 Plus.  I picked it over the Officejet Pro 8600 e because it's faster and holds more paper.  I didn't go with the Premium model because I did not need the second tray.  I can always buy a second tray later down the road if I really need it.  Another thing was that Amazon had the Pro model cheaper than Costco with free shipping and no sales tax.  For the money, it costs a bit more than the e model but less than the Premium.  Comparing the 8600 to other all in one such as the Epson lines, I ultimately decided that the 8600 Plus was a better buy in term of quality and cheaper per page printing cost.  I'm sure Epson fans out there will no doubt scream bloody murder over my personal assessment, but hey, when it comes to opinion, to each his own.The printer arrived yesterday via UPS and the packaging was in excellent condition.  Kudos to UPS for improving their delivery service and ensuring that the package arrived in one piece.  The content was neatly packaged and organized.  Several people commented that the 8600 was a fairly hefty printer.  I was a bit worried as to where I would put it due to its size.  When I unpacked it, I found that the length of the 8600 was about the same as the 7410xi while the width was smaller and the height was shorter than the 7410xi.  I have a small book case next to my desk, and the printer sits on top of it.  After I plugged in the printer and powered it up, the touch screen LCD display walked me through on setting it up.  If people took their time and not rush through the on-screen setup, the fat finger problem of selecting something other than what you wanted would not be an issue.  Connecting the ink cartridge to the printer was very easy.  As soon as I opened the front panel, the ink tray slide over and I just had to push in the corresponding color cartridge to the corresponding ink tray.  As soon as I closed the front panel, the printer took a few seconds to recalibrate the ink cartrige and print out a calibration page.Setting up the printer wireless was not so smooth.  Before I go on, the 8600 allows you to connect to the printer via wireless, ethernet (CAT 5 cable) or USB.  I opted for the wireless.  Once I assigned the printer to my home network, and obtained the IP address; by all indications, it is part of my home network and therefore my gaming computer running on Windows 7 64 bit should be able to recognize it on the network.  To my surprise, it didn't.  After a few futile attempts of trying to figure out why it was still not showing up, I opened up the Getting Started Guide.  It looked like HP knew of this and put the instruction to resolve it at the beginning of the Setup Wireless section.  Following the simple instruction, I powered off the wireless router, powered off the printer and even my gaming machine.  Then I powered up the router, printer and gaming computer.  Reinstalled the printer driver and it went through smoothly this time.  Guys, it's a good idea to crack open the guide every now and then even if you're a techie.  If I had done that first, I would not have run into snafu like I did and wasted about 20 minutes of my time.Next,having my ipad with me, I decided to test out the airprint feature.  WOW!  It works!  I then tested the airprint on my wife iPhone 4s, it too works.  My wife loves it, no longer does she have to open up email on her laptop in order for her to print it out.  I set up the eprint feature and enabled it so that my wife can print her google documents directly from the Chrome browser.  No longer does she have to either email the google doc to her home email address then print it, or having to save the google doc on her local computer directory, open it, then print.The printer is extremely quiet.  My wife could always tell when the 7410xi was printing even when she was up on the second floor.  The 8600 noise level is more like a whisper.Printing quality, excellent.  My wife bought 'HP Everyday Copy and Print' paper because it was on sale and like I said, the quality was excellent.  We also have high quality paper, but there was not a need for us to print on it.  I haven't print photos yet so I can't say for certain how photos look.  I can say that color printing using the HP paper that I mentioned produced a good color document result.  Ability to print 2 sided, awesome!  The same goes when making copies.I scanned photos and documents with great results.  You could either use the scan tool from the computer or from the printer touch screen.  The printer touch screen allows you to scan with the output going to the computer of your choice in your home network, memory device, network folder or email.I have not set up the fax feature so I cannot comment on it.Overall, I am extremely please with the HP Pro 8600 Plus.  I love the features, the beautiful, wide and brightly lit LCD touchscreen, and the results it produced.  It is definitely a worthy replacement to our old Officejet 7410xi.  If you're in a market for an all in one color inkjet printer, you can't go wrong with this one.  The Officejet Pro 8600 Plus deserves a 5 star rating from me.

Title: Truly Great Printer
Review: I've owned HP Printers for years.  The last two have not been good.  Horrible software, complex setup, long delays waiting to print and noisy.  I finally decided I had had enough of HP.  I researched for three weeks and ultimately tested my finalists in the store for speed, print quality and set up.  Despite my original intention .... I chose the HP Officejet Pro 8600.  It is AWESOME. Finally, HP got it right.  Brain dead simple set up that works time and again.  Lightweight software.  Fast quiet printing.  And the scanner is so simple to use - drops the scans right onto my computer.  Well done HP.  I liked it so much I bought a second for my office at work.  I highly recommend this product.  HP really got it right.

Title: HP New Wireless Printer 8600
Review: For the average home user this printer covers all the basics! I needed a fax machine occasionally and got tired of going to the Post Office or Library to fax something . Copy and Scans great from any room in the house. The only thing I find is ink is more expensive than HP competition! I would recommend this printer to anyone giving it 4 and 1/2 Stars !

Title: Printer problems
Review: I got the HP office jet Pro 8600 Plus e-all-in-on Wireless. I got it in last night and was excited to finally get a good printer. Well unpacking and installing everything was easy. The problem I ran into was when you first turn it on and the printer starts the alignment it would start to eat paper. I turned it off and check to make sure that I got all the packing tape or anything that might be blocking the paper. I did not see anything so I thought I might have put in to much paper, so I took out the paper to where only half was in the tray slot. I tried it again and still eat paper. I then called up HP support to see if they can help. HP was sort of helpful, the tech had me take off the back part that allows 2 side print and I was watching how the paper was coming through. I spotted right off why the paper was getting eaten. Seems a small white plastic paper guide was pushed in where all the others where not pushed in. So I pulled the guide out and tried the test print again. It worked after that. But it does make a noise that I am not used to and worry that there might be other problems right now it is working fine just makes a noise that I dont like. I will give it a week and see if anything else goes wrong.

Title: Features List & Comparisons: HP OfficeJet Pro 8600 Plus
Review: HP OfficeJet Pro 8600 Plus, $230- Print, Copy, Fax, Scan - standard all-in-one printer features- 12.4'H x 19.4'W x 18.1'D, 26.9 lbs - large for a home printer, but feels sturdy- 128MB Printer RAM - to hold faxes in memory, and for processing large print jobs- 1-yr Limited WarrantyInk Cartridges- pigment-based ink - more waterproof and fade resistant than dye-based inks- individual cartridge for each ink color - less wasteful than replacing a 3-ink cartridge- front panel access door - don't have to lift up entire scanner unit to change ink cartridges- ink cartridge memory chip usage info collection - can be turned offControl Panel- 4.3' Color Tilting Touch Screen Control Panel - nice readability- nice control panel interface design - good screen layout, straightforward menu navigation- 25 Control Panel Language Options - Bulgarian, Chinese/Simplified, Chinese/Traditional, Croatian, Czech, Danish, Dutch, English, French, German, Greek, Hungarian, Italian, Japanese, Korean, Norwegian, Polish, Portuguese, Romanian, Russian, Slovak, Slovenian, Spanish, Swedish, TurkishConnectivity- Ethernet Wired Networking, Wireless 802.11b/g/n Networking, USB 2.0 PC Connection - from single PC to entire network- Embedded Web Server - manage printer settings and fax services with a web browser, without needing to install printer software on PCFlash Drives, Memory Cards- Front USB 2.0 Port for Flash Drives - print documents from flash drive without going through a PC- Memory Card Reader: SDHC, Memory Stick, MMC - print photos without going through a PCPaper Handling- 1250 pages/month recommended usage (41 pages/day) - should be OK for home/home office use- slide-out paper tray holds 250 sheets plain paper - more convenient than fixed paper tray- paper tray holds 3 x 5' to 8.5 x 14', 16-lb paper to 110-lb card stock - good range of papers- paper tray holds envelopes (no manual feed tray) - less convenient than a manual feed tray- output tray holds 150 sheets plain paper output - should be enough for home/home office- no straight paper path - envelopes and thick papers more likely to curl and/or wrinkle- 50-sheet 2-Sided Auto Document Feeder - very nice for copying, faxing, and scanning 2-sided originalsPrint- fast print speeds - compared to comparably priced printers from Epson, Brother, Canon- auto duplex 2-sided printing - economical and convenient, slightly slows down printing- print directly from digital camera, connected as USB Mass Storage Device Class- print wirelessly through mobile device Android/Apple iOS apps - e.g. print iPhone pics directly- print through email and web connecitons - while away from home/officeCopy- Copy 1-Sided > 1-Sided, 1-Sided > 2-Sided, 2-Sided > 1-Sided, 2-Sided > 2-Sided- max 99 copies, 25% - 400% Reduce/Enlarge, Copy Preview; Poster, Clone, Mirror, Auto-EnlargeFax- 110 Fax Number Speed Dials, 120-Page Fax Memory - should be fine for home/home office use- Caller ID Junk Filter, Auto-Redial, Delayed Send, Fax Forwarding - standard fax features- Fax to/from PC - paperless fax send/receive- Auto-Archive Fax to Network Folder - convenient electronic auto-filing of received faxesScan- 8.5 x 14' Flatbed Scan, 8.5 x 14' ADF Scan - many other printers only scan up to 8.5 x 11.7'- scan to BMP, JPEG, PDF, PNG, RTF, TXT, TIF - good variety of image and text formats- OCR Software Included - convert text from paper to editable files- Scan to Network Folder - convenient auto-filing of scans- Scan to Email - can email scans without having to go through PCHP OfficeJet Pro 8600 Premium Comparison:- $300 vs. $230 - cheaper than buying 8600 Plus and then adding 2nd Paper tray, bonus ink & paper- ~2' taller, 7.5 lbs heavier (2nd Paper Tray adds height & weight)- 2nd Slide-Out Paper Tray; holds 250 sheets Letter/Legal/A4 plain paper only ($80 value)- standard-size ink cartridges vs. starter-size (?? value)- 50 Sheets HP Glossy Brochure Paper ($11 value)HP OfficeJet Pro 8600 Comparison:- $150 vs. $230- 0.6' shorter, 1.9 lbs lighter- 64MB Printer RAM vs. 128MB- 2.65' screen vs. 4.3' screen - less than  the surface area- fixed paper tray vs. slide-out paper tray- 35-sheet 1-Sided Auto Document Feeder vs. 2-Sided 50-sheet- slightly slower print speeds- no Network Folder Fax Archive- 8.5 x 11.7' Flatbed Scan vs. 8.5 x 14'- no Scan to Network Folder, no Scan to EmailHP OfficeJet 6700 Premium Comparison:- same as with HP OfficeJet Pro 8600, except for:- $160 vs. $230- slightly smaller, 7.8 lbs ligher- 128MB Printer RAM- smaller screen vs. 4.3' screen- no embedded web server?- no Memory Card Reader- ~600 pages/month recommended usage vs. 1250 pages/month- probably slower print speeds?- 99 Number Fax Speed Dial vs. 110 Number- 100-page Fax Memory vs. 120-pageEpson WorkForce Pro WP-4530 Comparison:- $200 vs. $230- taller & narrower, 3.5 lbs heavier- Control Panel Buttons vs. Touch Screen- non-tilting control panel - limits screen visibility, printer placement options- smaller screen vs. 4.3'- only English, French control panel languages vs. 25 languages- paper tray reportly less sturdy vs. Officejet Pro 8600 Plus paper tray- Rear Manual Feed Paper Tray (holds 80 sheets plain paper) - -straight paper path- slower print speeds- 30-sheet 2-Sided Auto Document Feeder vs. 50-sheet- 68 lb max paper weight (via rear manual feed) vs. 110 lb max- 60 Fax Number Speed Dial vs. 110 Number- 180-page Fax Memory vs. 120-page- no Network Folder Fax Archive- 8.5 x 11.7' Flatbed Scan vs. 8.5 x 14'- no RTF, TXT scan file formats- no Scan to Network Folder, no Scan to Email- no Memory Card ReaderEpson WorkForce 845 Comparison:- same as with Epson WorkForce Pro WP-4530, except for:- $170 vs. $230- narrower, 4.9 lbs lighter- must lift up scanner unit to access ink cartridges vs. front panel access door- 3.5' screen vs. 4.3'- Memory Card Reader also reads CF, xD vs. just SD, Memory Stick, MMC- 24 lb max paper weight vs. 110 lb max

Title: All-in-one for the e-world
Review: I purchased the Officejet 8600 Pro Plus about two weeks ago with amazing results.  I installed it in a closet downstairs and is only connected through my wi-fi network.  I have 4 computers that it serves and 3 mobile devices (2 smartphones and an iPad).  Setup was a breeze.....I love that touchpad!It prints fast and great but my primary use for this device was for the scanning.  The ability to scan to any of my computers, scan to e-mail, scan to USB device, or scan to SD Card has made document storage for me a hassle free process.  Hpeprint makes it just so easy to print any document from any device connected to the internet and an e-mail account.I cannot speak for the fax function because in my personal and business use I have not had the need to send or receive faxes.  I also do not have a landline.  I suspect this is still a popular legacy service in our mobile society?  Pretty hard to get a fax quote on a smartphone.The unit is quite large and a bit on the heavy side.  You will need a good size footprint.  The wifi reciever on the unit is very strong (goes through two floors and into a closed closet).  So far no errors and clean prints.  Very fast shipping from Amazon.

Title: HP officejet 8600 two-tray pro plus--A frustrating boondoggle
Review: I second a prior review in the following, also my exact experience: 'I was really, really, really looking for an all-in-one that could print legal sized paper and print envelopes easily. This does neither. It does have a legal sized flatbed for the scanner which led me to think that it could print legal sized paper. No such luck. Printing envelopes one at a time is possible but only if you remove the paper tray, remove all the paper in the tray, insert the envelope (or envelopes), print, remove the paper tray, re-insert the paper and re-insert the paper tray. Horrible. Horrible. Horrible.'Furthermore, I was doubly sucked in and ordered a second tray for printing legal and envelopes.  I spent hours with tech support, which I had no trouble reaching, trying to get one of the two trays to print only envelopes and the other only letter size.  I have stamps.com and called them and they said that they get a lot of calls on the 8600 and helped me download the software for the 6500 which actually works for the stamps.com printing of envelopes, but only on the Stamps.com site-thank you Stamps.com tech support.But, back to the HP software nightmare. I now have envelopes in tray 1, letter size in tray 2.  However, when doing diagnostics or print head cleaning etc. the HP automatically, despite the settings, defaults to tray 1 with the envelopes.  Can I tell you how very difficult it is to use this printer with the temperamental software. Furthermore, I must hand reset the printer each time to pick up from tray 2.  Furthermore, I try to save ink by printing in greyscale and all black, but the HP keeps resetting to use all the colors. I can't help to think that HP is now using some cut-rate outfit in Shanghai to lower labor costs and boost the bottom line for the Packard family, but not please the customer.  Perhaps they can get away with this for a while, but I would not buy stock in this company as they are headed for the exit is this is an indicator of their quality control.

Title: Very happy with this printer
Review: My HP 7100 was showing its age -- the worst thing about it was that the auto document feeder would feed a page or 2 and then get hung up -- so it was time for a new one.I did a lot of research, and like others have said, narrowed it down to this one and the Epson Workforce 845. The reviews of the Epson pointed out flimsier construction, higher cost of ink, and a couple of other things that didn't sound like a good fit for me. So I went with HP 8600 Plus and am very pleased with it.The box it comes in is pretty big, but at 64 I was able to get it into my car, out of my car into the house, remove the old one, unpack this one and lift it up onto the printer stand. Set up was a breeze on my Mac equipment, all the bells and whistles work perfectly, and eprint is pretty cool.Many reviewers say they can't get the 8600 Plus to load card stock. This worried me a lot so I just tried it. It didn't load the card stock when I put a sheet in the tray on top of regular paper, but when I took out the regular paper and loaded the card stock, it printed fine. I selected card stock when printing and had no trouble.I love the auto document feeder. I made a pdf out of about 40 pages and not one jam or glitch. The fax function is better than the old models, too. With the 7100 I couldn't leave the phone line plugged into it -- it thought every call was a fax no matter how I tweaked the settings. This one allows for my answering machine and hasn't once mistaken a voice call for a fax.All in all, I love it -- this all-in-one is worth every penny!

Title: Please look else where!
Review: I was really hoping this printer was going to be great.  It arrived perfectly, took it out of the box, plugged it in, followed directions to a T.  That's when the issues started.  It says something is wrong with the printer, the touch display doesn't work properly, and it is officially getting returned.  I guess I have one of the defective ones.  I really wanted this to be the right printer, but now I have to go back to the drawing board.

Title: HP tech support phone number
Review: Just received my printer, want to say this while it is fresh on my mind. I could not find a tech support phone number (if you need tech support) in the instructions/setup papers etc., so I am listing the number here because I had a difficult time finding it. HP Customer Care for Home: 800-474-6836, for business 800-334-5144. The support was decent but not fantastic. There are limits on what a person can do from China (or Indonesia or wherever) but she was courteous and understood me although I had a wee bit of difficulty understanding her. Make sure the duplexer, which you will have to insert into the rear, is clicked all the way in on both sides. My paper wouldn't feed until I got that right. The printer also initially said my ink was leaking somewhere, but it wasn't, and it took a printer restart to help it overcome that hurdle. When any print job or command gets bogged down on this printer (fax failure, ink leaking, photo print from software besides HP), it seems the only way to resolve the issue is to turn it off and then on again. Otherwise, so far, so good except couldn't get the fax to work even with the tech support lady. I will post again later if this printer turns out to be a disappointment.

Title: Best Printer!
Review: I have made the switch away from HP printers and couldn't be happier.  Currently I am running Mac OSX Lion, and it works great.  Ridiculously easy to set up.  Just make sure you lion users go to [...] an get the drivers there, not the CD.Also, really easy to print from my iPad!Also, if you scan a lot.  I recommended getting PDFScanner from the Mac App Store. It works great with this printer (and in general).Thanks Epson!

Title: Pours permanent ink EVERYWHERE
Review: STAY AWAY FROM THIS PRINTER!The printer indicated that I needed to change a color ink cartridge and would not print B&W until I did.  I changed it, and it still wouldn't print.  So, I changed it, again.  (This ink is expensive...)  Still wouldn't print.  So I unplugged it to return it and magenta ink poured everywhere.  Ruined a brand new pair of pants.It seems to me that I have had to replace an HP printer every year (and this one was 1 year and 10 days old), filling landfill with replaced product, but this is the last straw.  I am not out hundreds of dollars in damage from this thing.  GOOD-BYE HP...

Title: Thanks dude at Office Max
Review: I was just about to purchase another Canon so that I could wireless print around the house with Bluetooth when the cashier suggested I try HP... He informed me that over time I would save money because the ink cartridges for canon were so much more expensive when you considered how many pages per cartridge you can print.Then when I got it home I couldn't believe how awesome it was.  It's sleek and has a cool little touch screen pad.  But what's more is that I can set up an email and email the printer things to print off.  It's fabulous!  It was super easy to set up and I haven't had any problems with it since I purchased it.Favorite Features:Wireless PrintingEasy Set upTwo Sided Print (seriously this is awesome)Easy Load TrayThe ONLY reason that it doesn't have five stars is that it has been super noisy when two side printing. The wheels sound very very squeaky and that's annoying, but I'm not switching it!  Everything else about it is perfect - it makes me wish I had switched from Canon a long time ago!

Title: Great machine but HPNetworkCommunicator.exe just a bit annoying
Review: I was needing a color multi-function printer for scanning, printing and copying for home use. Faxing was not a requirement but ethernet connectivity was. After comparing various models in local stores and on-line, I bought the HP 8600 Plus. Amazon offered a better price than any local store and, as it turned out, shipping was faster than I expected.Setup of the printer was a breeze. It was straightforward with nothing out of the ordinary. Ink cartridge installation was simple. Replacement when the time comes should be also. Separate color ink cartridges is the way to go and is an added plus.Now after one month, I've used all of the 8600 features without problems (except faxing as it is not connected to any phone line). My in-home network is not wireless enabled, hence my ethernet connectivity requirement. Connectivity to my primary computer (Windows 7 64-bit) was established with ease once the printer was plugged into its local network switch and was on my network.After installing, connecting and using the HP 8600 Plus for several hours, I started noticing that my mouse pointer kept getting 'grabbed' every 15 seconds or so. The culprit turned out to be the recently installed 'HPNetworkCommunicator.exe' in 'Program Files/HP/HP Officejet Pro 8600/bin'. Apparently whether the printer is on, off, or in standby/sleep mode, HP's computer software checks its network connectivity and grabs or freezes the mouse pointer when doing so.I circumvented the issue by renaming the '.exe' to '.exeORIG' whenever I wasn't using the printer for network printing or for scanning documents to the computer. Scanning to other devices and copying work fine without that exe running - it's only needed for the desktop and printer to communicate. Whenever I need my computer to 'see' the printer again, I just rename the '.exeORIG' back to '.exe' and everything works as it should. When completed, I again rename it back to '.exeORIG' to avoid the constant interruptions.I don't know if that HP software issue is unique to ethernet connectivity, Windows 7 or if it exists with other installations of the printer and software. Regardless for something that should run in the background without impact, the 'HPNetworkCommunicator.exe' is much too disruptive while working with mouse-oriented programs on the computer.Despite the aggravation - since the rename 'fix' works for me - I give the HP8600 plus 4 stars. It does everything I need it to do - scanning photos or documents into jpg or pdf, one-sided or double-sided color printing and copying.

Title: First printer I ever bought that I'm actually happy with.
Review: HISTORYI finally got frustrated enough with my gigantic Brother MFC6490CW that I decided to replace it.  I'd originally abandoned my loyalty to HP printers, and switched to Brother, due to the bloated and intrusive software I had to use with my old OfficeJet 6110.  Unfortunately, the Brother had unreliable communications.  So it's back to HP.DEMOGRAPHICSMy wife and I both work from home so we really do need a fast, reliable, affordable, all-in-one type of printer that can work with multiple platforms such as Windows 7, Windows XP, OS X, and iOS.  We don't do a lot of photo or color printing so while it's something that's nice to have, it doesn't have to be top notch.  If we really need to print a photo we just take the file to Target or Walgreens, and if we need to create pretty, color brochures, we go to Kinko's.  This is a productivity oriented printer so if you need perfect color prints, you won't be happy with the results here.SETUP & INSTALLThe touchscreen interface is really quite nice; I'm not sure why everyone complains about it.  It's not a capacitive touchscreen like your smartphone (I'm guessing it's a resistive touchscreen) so it requires a little more force to activate than your smartphone.  This is hardly a big deal.  I'm not typing an essay on the thing, I just need it to respond to a few inputs now and then.  Because it's a touchscreen, it's able to dynamically change during setup to make setup intuitive.  No more guessing which button you need to press to do something.  It also has neat little videos that play on the screen during setup to show you how to do something, like install the ink cartridges, or any accessories.Following the recommendations of online reviews I read, I downloaded the software online rather than use the provided CD.  The software installed without a hitch on the Windows machines, found the printer, and was ready to go.  The software the Mac almost went in without a hitch, but for some reason the 'scan to computer' function wasn't available.  I re-ran the setup wizard and it magically appeared.So once that's all done, you are ready to go.  There's a lot of tweaking that you can still do though so if things aren't perfect, don't be disappointed.PERFORMANCEThe print quality is acceptable.  If you want to print photos for framing, don't buy this printer.  If you want to print fancy brochures, don't buy this printer.  This is an office printer.  It's actually in the name, 'OfficeJet'.  If you want a photo printer, HP has a solution for that and they call it 'PhotoSmart'.  Marketing people are so clever aren't they?  Anyway, the print quality is good enough for an office environment where you plan on printing document to share with colleagues, clients, or collaborators.  Also, this printer is fast, or at least faster than any other printer we've had in the office.  The only downside to fast is that you have to keep the output tray extended or your documents will be strewn all over the floor.FEATURESThe whole HP ePrint thing is new to me so you'll have to forgive me for getting excited about something that might be old hat.  My work PC (Windows XP) uses a VPN to connect to HQ and some underlying IT settings mean that once I hook up to the VPN, I can no longer print to my network connected printer, including this one.  With HP ePrint, however, I now have a clever workaround now!  For one thing, if I'm using Google Chrome as a browser and want to print something from there, I can use Google Cloud Print to send the document to my printer.  Setup of the HP ePrint feature is easy and free.  Unfortunately if I want to print something like a Word Document, I have to e-mail that document to my printer's e-mail address.  This isn't especially difficult, but it means I now have a bunch of large documents cluttering up my SENT folder.  The printer can handle most common documents types such as Word, PDF, text, etc...  The advantage here is that I can print to the device from any device with e-mail anywhere in the world.  Just send the file as an attachment to YOUR_ADDRESS@hpeprint.com and you're done.We don't send or receive many faxes so we don't have a dedicated fax line, but when we do need to send or receive a document, it's really nice if it just works.  Having to unplug and swap phone cables isn't a lot of fun and we don't have a lot of time to stand next to the printer waiting to see if an incoming call is a fax so we can press the RECEIVE button.  Many of the printers we've used before claim to have the ability to intercept incoming fax calls, but we've never had one work right.  This is the first exception.  Simply tell the printer what your phone/fax configuration and it adjusts its behavior to work.  In our case we have an answering machine.  The printer listens in on the call after the answering machine answers.  If it hears the beep beep beep of an incoming fax, it intercepts the call and receives the fax.  We have it setup to just store incoming faxes as a PDF document on our server rather than print them, but you can also have it send the faxes to you as an e-mail.Scanning is where we had the most pain with our old Brother.  The software would work maybe 75% of the time and no amount of troubleshooting could ever change that; it just depended on luck.  With the HP, those days seem to be over.  Scans, whether initiated from the printer or our workstations, go through without a hitch.  The nice part about scanning on this thing is that you have many options about how to handle your scan.  When operating the scan from the printer you can send it to your computer, a mapped network drive, an e-mail recipient, or an SD card.  You can also specify whether to save the file as a PDF, JPG, or TIFF.  You can have an address book stored on the printer for the purposes of e-mail documents, but alas you have to manually enter it; I've not found a way to import an address book.BOTTOM LINEI'm happy with the printer.  The price, features, and quality of print are exactly what we were looking for.  The quality of construction and the quality of the software are what I would expect from something in this price range.  The printer is a bit large, but again, it's an office printer.  Don't buy this for someone living in a dorm room; they will hate you.  This printer has restored my faith in HP printers and I'm seriously considering buying a PhotoSmart printer so we can avoid those very occasional trips to Target or Kinko's.

Title: 3/4 good 1/4 bad
Review: Had an HP 7310 all in one for 7 years and was great till type 'shuttered'.  Don't know how to fix so bought what I thought would do same.  The 8600 Pro is nice and set up easy and does all normal functions well.  I have the 8600A premier at work and thought this would be similar (only without the 2nd paper drawer that is broken already).  To my surprise:  this 8600 Pro won't feed heavy paper! You can't see the paper tray without pulling it out.  How do you feed an envelope?  You open tray pull out paper, put in envelop, adjust the guides and close and pray.  No bypass, no opportunity to just stick it in like the 7310 or like the 8600A Premier.  What a pain.  After seeing this feed I can't wait to be annoyed printing pictures!  Let me go do that and come back...not same paper size options...yup...tray out, 2 hands to load photo paper and be careful as guides are flimsy...funny, won't print borderless either!  But, actually gives paper options that say 'thick plain paper'.  Wonder why it will feed photo paper but not thick paper.  Got photos printed but don't match my album which is all borderless.  Scanner and faxing are great though so I guess I'll just be annoyed every time I want thick paper or photos.  HP should not make so many models.  Just perfect existing ones!

Title: Great office tool
Review: I was a little leary after reading some of the negative comments about the product but for me it's a dream machine, setup was quick and simple and as a network printer its great we have a small home office with a couple of computers and were sharing a network printer connected to one of the machines so I needed to leave the machine on all the time to have access to the printer with the 8600 that all goes away I can access it from either machine or use it as a stand alone copier and fax machine. Also the fax worked fine with my comcast phone which was a problem for the previous fax machine. All in all I'm very happy to have purchased the printer.

Title: Very Disappointed -- Exchanged for an Epson Workforce 845
Review: Let me first say that I have no affiliation with HP or Epson because my review might appear as though I do.  I've owned 5-6 multifunctional all-in-one printers dating back to the mid-1990s when they first came out.  The ink cartridge case on my Brother MFC-885CW cracked and so I did quite a bit of research to find a new multifunctional device.  It came down to the HP Officejet Pro 8600 and the Epson Workforce 845.  Having purchased an HP computer last year (which runs great), I decided to go with HP.  I was very disappointed.  It was difficult to set-up (most of my family and friends consider me the 'computer guy' in the house) and the paper kept jamming, especially when trying to print double-sided.  It also printed slower than my 3-yr old Brother printer.  In the end, I took it back to the store and decided to get the Epson Workforce 845, which was a huge upgrade (and cheaper).

Title: Officejet Pro 8600 Plus - Has Bugs with Windows XP
Review: I love this printed and it works great after a lot of work and frustration. This printer has a serious problem when using Windows XP. Every night the wireless system disconnects and the printer will not print in the morning. HP tech support tried to help, but they did not have thew answers. I called 4 times and their people could not solve the problem. I finally found a work around on the HP blog site. Now that this problem has been fixed this printer is great, works like a charm and is everything I wanted. Large paper tray is nice! If you are using Windows XP think twice and check the blogs. Otherwise this is a very nice printer, fax, copier, scanner. Here is the blog site. [...]

Title: Pleasantly surprised with Mac compatibility
Review: I fear this review might get lengthy, but I really wanted to give good information I myself was looking for online before I made the decision to purchase this printer.I'm a Mac user.  I had a series of Canon multi-function printers (MX860, MX870, MX882) over the years until a couple of weeks ago when the MX882, like its predecessors, inexplicably died.  Frustrated with Canon printers and the way they guzzle ink and are flimsily built, I decided to rethink my choice of Mac compatible printers and examine all of the readily-available units on the market.I like the concept of an all-in-one, and being a home user who only occasionally prints photos, scanning is more important to me, and needing an automatic document feeder (ADF) has proven to be more useful than I thought, so that was an important feature in my purchasing decision.  While there may be better photo printers out there, with specialized inks (gray, etc.), this unit has the standard 3-tank CMY color inks, but since I print photos so infrequently I would likely be just as happy with a good quality 3 color ink printer.I already have a Brother duplexing b/w laser printer on my network and love it.  My printing is more black-and-white anyway but occasional color and scanning is important.Things I was looking for: solid Mac compatibility (with OS X Lion).  Air Print compatibility (if possible).  Ethernet wired connectivity (don't care about WiFi).  Network scanning.  Automatic duplex printing.The Lexmark units looked good on paper, but apparently suffer in Mac compatibility department.  So too Epson, apparently.  Wouldn't go back to Canon (which seems to offer the best Mac support and Mac compatible software suite, even with OS X Lion).Ultimately I chose this printer.  So far, I'm really happy I did.Let me get this out of the way immediately - it comes with 4 'starter' inks.  I don't know how much I'll be able to print with them before having to buy new cartridges, but separate ink tanks for black and colors is an absolute requirement -- and I like the idea of being able to use 'XL' ink cartridges, which should be good for about 700 color pages of output and up to 2,000 b/w pages.  The other thing that isn't optimal about this unit is that the scanner technology is CIS, not CCD.  CCD in my opinion produces much higher quality scans, but units that have CCD scanning sensors in them cost a lot more money (Canon MG8220 for example).Setup -- quite easy...  Ahead of time, go buy some decent printer paper.  Better quality than the stuff that is  coarse recycled general purpose copy stock.  My local office supply depot had 625 sheet high brightness quick dry paper for inkjets for four bucks a pack.  Snap in the duplexing unit on the back, snap in the four starter inkjet cartridges, use the touch screen to walk through the setup process, and you're up and running.  If you're a Mac user with OS X Lion, don't use the included CD, they tell you not to, instead download the install disk image from HP's website and go from there.  It went well, quickly, and it works great.Features - quite good.  You configure the printer for network scanning by configuring computers you want to be able to save the scans to across the network.  Configure the computer name, the share name, the id and password to use, and it's good to go.  I configured my home NAS as one destination, my iMac as another.  Also configure the printer to be able to receive e-mail from anywhere in the world and it will print the e-mail and any supported attachments (you can limit who it's allowed to print e-mail from).  Also configure your printer to scan and send e-mails right from the printer.  There's so much you can do right from the printer without needing a computer.  Plug in a supported memory card or USB thumb drive and print photos right from there.  Scan to USB thumb drive or memory card.  Print from your iPhone or iPad using AirPrint.  It all works really well so far.The scanning software included with Lion can work with this printer right over the network.  HP also includes  scanning software that lets you do similar activities.  You can also download 3rd party scanning software like VueScan which I tried for grins, it works great with this scanner.Really, unless this thing demonstrates flaky behavior or that it guzzles ink like the Canon did, I'm really sold on it and couldn't be happier with my purchase.  I really expect that once I buy the XL black cartridge, I will make this my primary printer and maybe put the networked laser printer out to pasture.One note, it's kinda big...  The ADF sits tall on top of the unit and to scan you need to tilt the document cover (including ADF) back to access the scanner glass; make sure you have clearance above and behind.  Oh, and the scanner glass is legal size (8.5 x 14).

Title: Epson or HP
Review: I sent 1.5 hours comparing the scanning, print quality, and print speed of numerous 200+ dollar printers.  It came down to Epson and HP, namely the Epson 845 and HP 8600 pro plus.  I'll make this easy, the HP is the way to go.  The only strength I could find on the Epson is retail pricing, but HP discounts are so strong that you can get a HP 8600 pro plus for 17 dollars more then the Epson 845.  The Epson at Micro Center would print horizontal lines on copies and scans, the HP has much less of this(but there were noticeable horizontal lines).  The HP prints much faster, period. They both take extra large ink tanks as an option.  I have never seen faster ink jets then the hp in this price range.  Yes, Epson claims it is faster at two sided, but it is marginal, in fact I would say that it is pure marketing of taking your one mild advantage and strongly touting it.  The HP 8600 are very solid, don't have flimsy paper trays, and have one killer app that makes this a no decision....apps.Most of the apps are worthless, however, some apps, like the ability to to scan directly to google docs, are, if you use google docs to run a paperless office like me, a dream come true.  Plus there will be more apps in the future.  The apps are very robust, especially with the color touch screen.  Also, the printer updates its firmware over the net and it pretty quick about it.  I don't know if or how Epson 845 compares.The wireless integration between computer and printers is seamless and very easy to setup, I don't know how the Epson compares, but it can't be any easier then HP.  The packaging on the HP is the smartest I have seen, the printer is in a bag that you can easily lift out of the box.  It is a very considerate feature and makes getting the printer out of the box quick and easy.The Epson has a few notables strengths, price, the fact it flips the page back to face up on two sided scans (at least it seemed to do that), and less confusing naming.  HP has a 8600, 8600 pro, 8600 pro plus, and 8600 pro plus premium.  Its crazy, and the prices are all over the place.  I was willing to pay 300 for the pro plus but then it went on sale for 225 at BB, its 217 here.  If you are worried about $50 between printers then don't by a printer, the ink over time is what kills and the 50 you save will be nothing compared to the 200 in ink with even light usage, at least these printers have XL tanks that save you roughly 50% over time which is huge given the cost.  The key is to find deals on ink, and oem ink is the way to go if you can.So I give the HP 5 stars, and the Epson 3.  Its good enough, but does not match the HP line in software sophistication, quality of construction, and speed.  The level of innovation in the HP is really shocking at this price.

Title: I love this printer
Review: This is the 3rd HP printer that I have owned.  Each one better than the previous one.  This printer is great.  There are many features, some of which I have not tried.  It prints super fast.  I love that you can feed the paper from the top or from a tray.  The 2-sided printing feature is the best, and I really appreciate that when you are printing several pages it automatically collates....great, great, great.Scanning, faxing....everything you need.

Title: LOVE THIS PRINTER
Review: WOW!!!  This machine is absolutely FANTASTIC!  I've had 4 other multi-function inkjets years ago and 4 different laser printers in the more recent past and thought lasers were the best.  Wow, I was soooo wrong!!!This multi-function inkjet prints WAY BETTER than I ever imagined it could and I don't think I will ever go back to cheap inkjets or expensive lasers!This was simple to install!  Updates come in to my email and when I click 'yes' to install, it does it automatically!It prints on both sides of the paper and is FAST!It has a touch screen on the front, all functions work as described, and I just can't say enough about how happy and proud I am to own the wonderful officejet...WOOHOO!!!

Title: Won't print magenta
Review: I purchased this printer through Amazon Warehouse Deals as a "used - very good condition" printer. It obviously had been defective from the beginning as the previous owner left a book with a picture of a red apple on the copy glass - presumably testing the ability of the printer to print red. Even after following HPs troubleshooting steps (and wasting expensive ink in the process), the magenta never worked. I tried it with the ink cartridges that came with the printer and again with brand new ones I had purchased. Thankfully I was able to easily return the printer. I ended up purchasing another Officejet Pro 8600 (just not the Plus model, as I decided the extra features weren't worth the additional money) because I didn't want to waste the $140 worth of ink I had purchased and opened. To my relief, the new printer seems to be working flawlessly.I didn't test everything else on this printer as it seemed pointless with the magenta not working.

Title: exceeds expectations
Review: great features; all the expected and more, including printing from my I Phone.My experience with HP products has always been very positive.

Title: HP Officejet Pro 8600 Plus e-All-in-One Wireless Color Printer
Review: Overall, a great product!  Very easy set-up, and wireless capabilites are awesome! Highly recommend this printer for all of your print, copy, scan needs!

Title: good printer and easy to use
Review: My only complaint is how short a time before the ink is gone, and unless you choose best printing, streaks can occur on glossy prints.

Title: fast print but really lousy color images
Review: prints fasteasy to set upquality of color images on prints is not good at allwe had a lexmark - ink was outrageousshopped around to get a replacement - we chose this one after looking at many models/brandsdisappointedwish we had gone with another model.

Title: Best printer/scanner I've ever owned
Review: I love this printer. It prints quickly. I do not have to replace the ink often. It scans well on the screen and the document feeder. It's also great for small amounts of copies. Would definitely recommend. I use it for my home business.

Title: Unbelievable low price
Review: I bought this printer for $100 less than any of the local retailers. It was delivered in the original factory packaging in perfect condition. Easy set up and it prints high quality prints.

Title: Excellent For The Money
Review: Easy set-up - has every feature that was on our wants/needs list. Very pleased with this home/business printer.  I think you'll like it too.

Title: A Winner!
Review: It does what it is supposed to quickly, efficiently and flawlessly. I am very pleased with it overall and its rating as a business class printer is well deserved.

Title: HP Printer
Review: So far it has been a good printer. I like the duplexing feature on it. It has a tendency to skew the originals at times, but outside of that it is not bad.

Title: Great printer at a great price
Review: The new HP 8600 Pro is easy to set up, easy to use, and produces great print copy. The color copies are great and the black print is very crisp and clean. I purchased it specifically for it's ability to print double-sided and I'm very pleased with the results. Initially, I could not decide between the Epson Artisan 725 and the HP 8600. The Epson will print onto CDs & DVDs (which the HP apparently does not do) and the HP prints double-sided (which the Artisan does not do). I have been very pleased with my selection of the HP 8600.

Title: HP Printer
Review: I was surprised when the printer arrived in the size, but once we got it set up it was Great.  I like the speed at which  copies are produced, love the top feed feature.  It is really nice when you have packets of materials to copy.  The 250 sheet paper tray is also great. I am a big fan of the back to back feature that allows the printing to be complete without having to reload the sheet into the machine.  The running of the machine is very easy as all of the prompts on the work panel are clear and the touch screen systems is easy to us.  However, it is up to you to take time to read the inclosed materials if you allow yourselve to get everything out of the machine.

Title: Great printer
Review: This printer does everything.  And emailing to an address to print something is great.  It even works if you send attachments and pdfs.  I can print easily with my phone.  The best is how long the cartridge lasts.  I've printed hundreds of pages already, and the ink level has barely gone down at all.  The only downside is this printer WILL NOT accept card stock.  I wanted to print business cards and tried many times, and it will not take in thick paper.

Title: Seems OK.
Review: Just bought this printer from Costco.  Set up was easy.  Connected to the wireless w/o a problem, and no problems installing to computer.  This came 'bundled' and i'm not sure what extra that gets you.  Maybe a few cords, but if you are going wireless, you don't need them.Pros: Like the both the scan to email and sending the printer an email from my iphone and it printing the document.  Quite nice features.  Printing seems decent.  We print a lot of color brochures and it is about the same quality as our old hp6480.  Didn't see much color difference between normal and best though.  Not as rich color as say a laser or probably some of the better photo printers.Cons: Scanner is not great.  Have to be at at least 200 dpi for it to come out clear and that puts one page at round 1MB.  We are using this for our real estate biz, and will not be able to scan a 20 page contract and actually email it to someone, since it would be 22MB.  Currently can not refill ink at costco.Still a little up in the air about whether we are going to keep it.  I think if you are planning to use this for home use, it would work just fine (my parents have one an love it) but if you are planning on doing a lot of scanning look else where.

Title: DO NOT BUY THIS PRINTER
Review: Just got off the phone with HP support because my 5 month old 8600 has been leaking ink as fast as I can put more in. They have no fix for it and the customer service rep said '2-3 printer out of every 100 are defective, you just got one of the defective ones' and offered for me to buy a 200$ replacement printer! Horrible customer service- and defective product!! Look at complaints around web before buying- this leaks ink!

Title: A Good Value for the Money!
Review: Overall, I am happy with this printer. I got it for a good price and the print quality is very good. Set-up was painless and I am able to print and scan easily. My only two complaints are:1. The initial print is slow. Once it gets started the speed is good. But the delay between when I press 'print' to when it actually prints lags a bit.2. My other complaint is that it will not print card stock...at all. I had read this on a few other reviews but I don't need card stock often so figured it wasn't a big deal. When I asked the salesman about it at Office Max, he assured me that was only if I was printing 10 or 20 card stock pages at a time.
